reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 is pretty cool, I guess. I mean, if you like having post traumatic stress disorder.

RO2:RS:MTV, is the sequel to Red Orchestra, which in turn is a sequel to an Unreal tournament 2004 mod called Red Orchestra, which in turn is a prequel to Battlefield: bad company 2: Vietnam.

The game takes place during WW2, a time in history when it was okay to wear a fedora, and it was only this time, so cut it out. Red Orchestra 2 focuses heavily on multiplayer, which is bad for me because that means I have to talk to people, which is bad for them because they can't understand meth induced slurring. Even with its multiplayer focus, the game manages to carry a narrative, and that narrative is We should probably stop having these wars

reviewText:
My most memorable moment in this game was probably when my friend and I went ahead and decided to learn how to drive a tank in the midst of battle.

When we spawned in, our tank crew went as follows: My friend as the driver, me as the person manning the tank's actual gun, and a random person operating the machine gun. Our crash-course, self-led tutorial basically consisted of my friend driving in circles because he could hardly see anything out of the driver's slit; me not being able to shoot the gun properly because the tank was constantly moving, resulting in tank shells being fired haphazardly around; and the machine gunner, who knew what he was doing, yelling at us and calling us incompetent idiots. I proceeded to accidentally pop my head out through the tank's top, only to instantaneously be shot. My dead body slumped back into the tank cockpit and awkardly jostled there as everything in the tank was suddenly painted with my blood. I can imagine Russian soldiers peeping out of their foxholes, only to comically spectate a German tank spin around, firing randomly and carelessly.

Later in the siege, our commander called in artillery on friendly positions and we lost.

I think they actually kill employees to record the game's death screams. Red Orchestra 2 can easily be named 'PTSD Simulator 1942.'

Seriously, though. This game is great. Easily one of the best World War II shooters I've ever played. Shots kill you instantly (If you're lucky enough to survive a bullet, you usually just sit in sadness as you listen to your character scream or cry to death as they bleed out), the carnage feels authentic and the atmosphere is truly war-like. The developers really harped on realism, and I can say they nicely achieved it.

That's not to mention the soundtrack is proud and patriotic, while at the same time solemn and depressing.

The only problems I can think of is the game are its graphics-intensive nature, so you need a decent computer to run it, and the game is so structured around teamwork that an incompetent team can really rain on your gameplay experience (Or boost it, depending on the scenario).

reviewText:
Day 1 - We deployed to the Eastern Front a week ago. Heinrich took some shrapnel in his arm, but he'll be alright. He got sent home. Progress is fast. We're pushing out the Bolsheviks at a large rate. We're at the gates of Stalingrad.

Day 4 - We've pushed past the defenses. Casualties were high... Johann didn't make it. Neither did Albert. Johann got shot by one of their sharpshooters. None of us were able to get to him. He bled to death... Albert got killed by a grenade. At least his death was quicker and more merciful.

Day 5 - Got a letter from my mother back home. Heinrich is recovering well, but will not be returning. The shrapnel severed ligaments in his arm. The men are glad to hear that he doesn't have to come back. This place is really going to hell very quickly...

Day 13 12:00 - We were ordered to take a train station yesterday. Close quarters fight. Very nasty. Albrecht got his skull crushed by a Soviet using his rifle as a club. Saw another boy, no older than 19, gutted with one of their spike bayonets. He lied there on the floor crying for his mother as his intestines were spilling out.

....what are we even doing here?

Day 13 17:21 - Soviet counter-attack. Three more of the original squad died today in an artillery bombardment. Two died from more close quarters brawls. We repelled the attack... but at too high of a cost, in my opinion. I would suggest that we destroy the tracks at multiple points and abandon the area... it holds no real tactical value anyway. Operative word being would." I'd rather not get shot by "Herr General" for "cowardice
recommended: and insubordination."\n\nDay 21 - Replacements finally arrived. Is it just me
hoursPlayed:
or are they accepting them younger? We were pushed out of the train station. We have no plans to take it back... yet.

Day 22 - Tomorrow we're supposed to attack somewhere... they didn't tell us where yet.

Day 23 - We took the hill called "Mamayev Kurgan." This place holds no strategic value at all... why did we take it? "Because we can."
...No members of the original squad are left except for myself and Karl. I had a grenade explode no more than 5 feet away from me. How am I still alive? I'm getting tired.

Day 26 - More replacements have shown up. I'm not even going to bother to learn their names anymore. They just get killed... The Soviets across the park keep playing their anthem over loud speakers. The ones that are closer to us are yelling at us
voteText: presumably insults. We insult back.\n\nDay 29 - We're holed up in an abandoned
helpfulPercent: bombed out
votesHelpful: apartment building.\n\nDay 30 08:16- I saw the funniest thing. Last night

reviewText:
I played this for three hours, went to work, someone dropped a plate and I ♥♥♥♥ myself.

Now for the actual review.
Regardless of any technical issues, this game is a truly underrated multiplayer experience. It is a beautiful perspective that can put you first person inside of a tank when an explosion hits, and you look around to find your commander missing. You later discover that your commanding officer's leg is now sitting in your lap, and realize the task that you must now complete while down a man. You may be traveling through the trenches only to have your buddy get his head ripped apart by a sniper round, while the lower body of your team's sniper flies right past you. Sure there are some glitches and bugs, but this game is truly different from any other fps in that you feel as if you're actually in the action, losing your friends to snipers and grenades.


When your squad falls around you
date: it's up to you to hold that position until reinforcements arrive. It doesn't matter how many times you've been hit
recommended: what percentage of your friend's body is intact
hoursPlayed: or how many men are trying to kill you. It's when you see dwindling numbers on your team's resupply that you realize how many men have died for you

reviewText:
Do you like dying to enemies you can't see?
Do you like dying in one shot, or bleeding out while screaming to death?
Do you like trying to snipe, only to miss targets by a mile?
Do you like getting mown down 20 times by a machine gun?

You answered NO to all of those.

Now, get off your fat ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, pick up a PPSh-41, and run into the bullets for Mother Russia.

Eventually you'll learn how to blyat Fritz to death, and I'll ask you this:

Do you like killing enemies that didn't even see you?
Do you like one-shotting enemies with that bolt-action of yours like a true cowboy?
Do you like getting a 800 meter shot on some ♥♥♥♥♥♥?
Do you like mowing down the enemies that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly sprint at your machine gun?

Then play Red Orchestra 2.

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 is a brilliant multiplayer team-based fps that made me remember why I love the genre. Based on the Battle of Stalingrad at the Eastern Front of WW2, the game is remarkable in it's attention to detail and authenticity.

The weapon handling/mechanics feel great, as do the ballistics. This coupled with the realistic level of damage players receive, makes for a highly rewarding combat system. The feeling of successfully rooting out a Sniper or MG with one well-placed shot, and freeing up your team's advance is incredible.

This is a game in which teamwork is paramount, the attacking team must capture and sometimes destroy objectives to advance to victory. This is facilitated (in theory) by the Commander and Squad Leaders, who each have an extremely important role to play.

The Commander has access to radios located in various spots around the map. From these, he can call recon planes to check enemy movement, force respawns and call artillery strikes which can turn the momentum of a game completely.

A good Commander is a necessity, as he will stategize on the fly, give the Squad Leaders and their teams objectives to complete and decimate enemy reinforcements with artillery.

The Squad Leaders need to know their stuff, as they posses the means to mark artillery targets in the form of binoculars and also serve as a mobile spawn point. Above all else the Squad Leaders job is to mark artillery targets for the Commander when asked, and to stay alive close to the objective. This allows for a constant stream of attackers to keep the pressure on the enemy, before he becomes entrenched.

There are 12 different squad roles in RO2, depending on the map being played and whether there is a tank present. The most common roles are Rifleman, Elite Rifleman, Assault, Elite Assault, Marksman, Machine Gunner, Squad Leader and Commander.

On maps with a tank there will also be roles related to tank operation and destruction. Each of these classes have a specific role to play, most of which is pretty self-explanatory. When a team is working together cohesively with a competent Commander and good Squad Leaders, it is one of the most intense and enjoyable games I have ever played.

RO2 is a game that takes a lot of time and effort to learn, and to a new player it can seem very overwhelming and difficult. If you are new to RO2, my best advice would be to role-play as a soldier in WW2. If you were in that situation, would you run across a street covered by an MG or into an artillery strike? If you treat your life as valuable, use cover, check your approach and move as a team you are much more likely to succeed.

This game definitely had a terrible launch, and suffers from some clunky mechanics and strange glitches (being stuck in between crouch and prone is a personal fav). While some of these issues will be enough to turn some people off, those that persevere will find a unique, rewarding and immensely satisfying game. With the constant stream of awesome community-made maps and the addition of Rising Storm, I couldn't recommend it more highly.

http://youtu.be/C9mpGlZVMlE

reviewText:
This game, is an absolutely amazing game. It is set in and around Stalingrad, where the Germans and the Russians face off for victory. It is also set in and around the South-East Asian-Pacific region, where the Japanese and the Americans face off for victory. It is brutally realistic and gritty. A bullet from most weapons to the torso will kill you most of the time, same to the kneck or head. To the arms or legs most of the time it will wound you. Even if you are not killed after being wounded, if the wound is anywhere other than your limbs, you must patch yourself fast or you will bleed out, just like in reality. If it is in your limbs you may or may not bleed out, sometimes you have to judge if its better to run to cover and then heal, or heal on the spot and hope you don't get shot again. Or maybe you don't need to heal at all and you can save your bandages for worse wounds. The weapons have realistic recoil, and clear advantages and disadvantages for all situations. The Germans favor medium to long range fighting, the Russians medium to short range. The Germans and Russians are both perfectly capable of attacking and defending, but the Germans have an edge when it comes to attacking due to having longer ranged weapons, the only assault rifle in the world at the time, and machine guns with very high rates of fire that are very good for pinning the enemy down. The Russians have an edge on defense due to being good at letting the enemy come to them and grinding them down in close quarters fighting, along with the superior PPSH 41 sub machine gun, and superior mosin nagant bolt action rifle with its amazing accuracy that can blow the enemy away at close range even with sloppy aiming. Basically, some weapons for one side are superior to the other's equivalent. The audio in this game is stunning and extremely intense, much better than other shooters. This game is also extremely reliant on team work, no one-man armies allowed. If one team is communicating and working together, and the other is not, then the team that is working together will crush the other one. If both are doing what they are supposed to be doing then you get incredibly intense matches.

The Rising Storm side of the game is pretty different from the Stalingrad part, for example Asymmetric warfare plays a huge role. The Japanese cannot face off against the Americans head on in open areas, the Americans just have too much fire power. The Japanese need to utilize the environment to keep mobility over the enemy and to take cover, jungle fighting is where they excell. All of the American riflemen have semi-automatic rifles, something neither the Japanese, nor the Germans or Russians get to have for their riflemen, and riflemen make up the bulk of the team. All of the other American classes have gear with superior raw damage and rates of fire to that of the Japanese, but what the Japanese excell at is their ferocity, combined with ingenious things such as creating frag grenade booby traps, knowing when to keep their distance so as to pick the enemy off from long range with their more accurate and longer range bolt action rifles, their knee mortars, and banzai charging in a small area in a big spearhead with smoke grenades and mortar/artillery/naval barrage support. The Japanese are definitely more geared towards attacking so as to hit the Americans on their terms and to overwhelm them in massed attacks, whereas the Americans, due to their superior raw fire power, are best on defense because they can dig in and if the Japanese run around in open areas they can mow them down like German machine guns on D-Day (Saving private Ryan style)

And speaking of D-Day, there is currently a 1944-1945 US vs German mod in development with testing events every few days, which will be like a fan made expansion which will bring the game up to 3 different theaters.

And on top of that a World War I mod is in the early stages of development with both western and eastern front gameplay.

There are no hackers whatso ever, there are some modded maps that are optional to play on, and the vast majority of the player base are cool people, who don't mess around, are not casual, and who play to win, all of which creates an extremely intense gaming experiance.

This game is one of the best games I have ever played, and I HIGHLY recommend it to everyone.
It's way better than what Call of Duty and Battlefield have turned into.

Some guy pretending he's Russian shouts URAAAA over and over again over mic. He gets hit, blood spilling everywhere and starts crying in agonizing pain. He tells me that it isn't safe and to push on. I hear other players over mic telling me to leave the area. Too many damn enemies. I go down instantly and do nothing while the injured man is on the ground next to me still crying. More men join us the in the trench and provide covering fire. Somone shouts ♥♥♥♥ING RUN NOW! I decide to push on and run for it. Suddenly I hear an explosion go off behind me and turn around to see bodies and limbs flying. One of the soldiers is crying....his character was pretending to talk to his mom about a booboo. Another explosion goes off closer to me and I keep running to join some other teamates. The guy who got shot joins me at the next stand off. Greets me over mic in silly but hearty russian accent
*each death gets us closer to victory eh comrade?* He runs off into enemy fire shouting URAAAA.

Get it for th-URAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

reviewText:
The year is 1942.
The weather is cold.You can't feel your fingers and you move them before the blood inside them turns into ice.You look at your weapon.It is full of scraches and the wood is rotten.
You can see soldiers around you.Some young, some old, fathers, brothers....

Every single one of them fighting for Survival, Country and Brotherhood..

Suddenly you hear a voice.Someone is talking to you. That man is your leader.He had been in war since 1939 and he has seen stuff that you hope you never see in your life.He knows how to survive and now he will try to keep you alive at any cost.

He makes a  short speech about death and Victory.He calls the enemy cowards or pigs so it boosts your moral. However once the attack beggins, everything turns into hell...

Men screaming in pain for someone to help them... you can hear them crying and screaming for a minute or so until they bleed to death.A lake of blood surounding their bodies.You are start loosing your sanity. Your own self.  Dirt and rocks from explosions thrown in the air.Dead rotten bodies everywhere you look.People getting blown to pieces or cut in half by machinegun fire.water in rivers and streets is red...You can hear bones and ribs breaking in the distance as the Heavy Tanks roll on  the dead bodies of men. Some of these soldiers under these tanks are still alive and they scream for help....again no one can help them.....
Their screams will be stuck in your mind....forever..   AAHHHHHHH!!! AAAAAAHHHHHHHHH!!!! H-HELP ME! HELP AAARRGHH!! MOM PLEASE HELP ME! I DONT WANT TO DIE LIKE THIS! NOT NOW! Aagh...!

..Your  ears are ringing...  Your vision is blurred and your mind can't think anything....
....All these young men lie dead around you.You must get up and fight to survive.

You look at your weapon....it is full of scraches and the wood is rotten....you pick it up and clean the dirt out of the rusted bolt...You take your clip with your frozen fingers....You load the gun. and you take a deep breath....

..Everything my boy...everything is up to you now... God be with you.

reviewText:
Prologue: NO I IN TEAM.

Some of the best moments I've ever had playing video games came during the era of Battlefield 2 + 2142. For me, the introduction of Commanders and Squad Leaders - with points granted for following orders - was something entirely unique. Working in tandem with a bunch of strangers, usually without the use of a mic, with the single goal of victory in mind, generated a greater sense of accomplishment through victory than the pursuit of a positive kill / death ratio. Unfortunately, the playing community on these games has dwindled, while the likes of Call of Duty, with its multi-platinum sales, has dictated the way in which EA has demanded DICE produce further editions of the series. Truly there was a gap in the market, with the only alternative fps that would cater for me being Counter Strike; which in itself was an entirly different animal. There may have been alternatives I didn't know about, namely the first Red Orchesta, but this was a game that never came onto my radar.

Fast forward a few years as the numbers dwindled on the 2142 servers, forcing me to find an alternative. After some minor research, I syumbled upon Red Orchestra 2, and what can I say, it ticked every box including ones I didn't realise existed or even needed ticking. If Battlefield 2 / 2142 encouraged team-play, RO2 demanded it; always will a well disciplined team, of average players, armed with an intelligent Commander reign victorious over a team of brilliant individualists. Of course, the game does give perks for team work, such as extra points for assist kills and defending cap zones etc. but lacking these bonuses, team-work would still be the back-bone of this game as the player-base knowingly understand it is the only way defeat can be avoided, even if it doesn't necessarily guarantee success, as the opposition will more than likely fight fire with fire.

General Pros and Cons:

PROS:
#More mature player-base - having kids flame out on VoIP is an extreme rarity.

#Campaign mode - a more involved an enlongated way to sew map victories together, as each team vies to hold each territory by succesfully attacking and defending on the campaign map.

#Map Design - Sure the player limit is capped at 64 & the maps are usually quite large - Bridges of Druzinha springs to mind - but the fact only one or two objectives are ever in play means the action is condensed into one section of the map. While player respawns act as single waves coming from a relatively sizable distance away. The pace of a packed server is quite remarkable, with each contol point always within 1 good attack from falling.

#Vehicles - Despite a couple of 'tank only' maps (which are avoided like the plague by the community) the maps only ever have one tank per side; one tank for the attacking team - to add some balance - or none at all. This keeps the infantry as the most relevant forces on the map, which should be the case in a FPS; while keeping a wild card in the pot at all times if not dealt with appropriatly.

#Team Balance - Both the Germans and the Russians have their strong and weak points. The Assault class is probably the most varried between the two armies, so I will talk about the differences a little. The PPS SMG for the Russians is unparalleled in close quarters and can take out entire squads with a rapid firing of bullets; however, when engaging anything over 50 meters it quickly becomes far less useful than the German Mp40. While, the Germans have access to the mk42b (arguably the games best all-rounder) for experienced Elite Assault troops. Like I said with pretty much every other class, the difference in guns in negligable. This minor differences means that certain maps are delibaretly avoided or chosen in Campaign mode, as it may bring out the best in a particular weapon - namely the over-powering of the PPS in the level Appartments.
Furthermore, each team can only have certain amounts of each player type, meaning that more than half of the battleground consists of regular rifleman armed with a bolt action non-scoped rifle - amplifyig the importance of knowing how to play your class.

#Fair leveling system - Most the upgrades awarded for leveling up provide major upgrades for extremely situational circumstances; bigger magazines for an smg or a bayonette for a rifle. This means that a lvl1 private entering the game for the first time doesn't have to be out-gunned while he builds up a feel and understanding of the game, while it also provides an incentive for experienced players to level all the available classes.
The only exception really comes with the sniper classes, who can swap out their bolt-action rifles for semi-auto rifles afer leveling up enough - although if it takes you multiple shots as a sniper, you're doing it wrong - or indeed the German Elite Assault class, who can unlock the games only Assault Rifle the MK42b - but on the flip side the Russians will have unlocked the drum magazine for their pps at this stage, which can inflict unimaginable carnage in certain circumstances.

#Steam Workshop - Addons provided by the community for free, what's not to like?

CONS:
#Realistic damage - a positive in my eyes, but I know people have complained about the inability to fire back at an aggressor. Nine times out of ten, spotting the enemy before they spot you means they will be the one filled with bullets. A good knowledge of the map layout aswell as ensuring the team has secured the flanks is of paramount importance.

#No weapon points for leaving a round - Annoyingly, if you leave a game prior to the end of a round, any of the points that you would have gathered for leveling up your weapons will be lost. Not too big of an issue you would think, but maps like Bridges of Druzihna have a one hour time limit, so you could lose 45 mins of good progress because real-life kicks in.

#Steep learning curve - Unlike some games which have beginner only servers, RO2 will not hold your hand at all, meaning that learning the intricacies of the game can be a grind which leaves your character in the grave more times than you would have liked.
The fact each team only has a set number of 'premium' classes also means that if it is clear you do not know how to play one of these roles, you'll be a considerable liability for your team. The only way of getting comfortable with a role is either through the games atrocious single-player campaign, or by spending time on a server populated solely by bots (there are many), just so your learning experience doesn't hinder the fun of others.

#Auto balance - Some matches can be incredibly one sided, due to team-work over VoIP or better use of Commander or Squad Leaders, and while the game does have an auto-balance feature it rarely pans out that it gets the switches correct.

It is a delight to see that Tripwire Interactive didn't cave into the pressure that was created by the rise of the modern console twitch-based shooter, ala Call of Duty. This game is a gem, that may not appeal to everyody, but certainly fills a gaping hole in the market that was brought on by a barrage of sub-par fps games. Indeed since its release there have been a few more gems that cater to a similar audience, none more so than the RO2 add-on Rising Storm, which is based on the Pacific Theater of WW2. It keeps much of the same gameplay mechanics, while injecting it with a completely different pace through level-design and weapon variation; meaning it offers enough of a change to make it worth the investment while keeping enough of the original so you know you'll like it if you liked RO2. Also, check out Insurgency for similar mechanics on a smaller scale.

This is by someway a marked improvement from the games which I had craved, as the team-work aspect is necessary for success; you are more likely to find team driven players on any random server here than during the golden-years of Battlefield.

reviewText:
I am a loyal soldier of the Red Army - a simple partisan, I have and always will be a Red Army soldier, regardless of the threat posed by the German Army's well-equipped, better trained soldiers.

Over the course of my years as one of Ivan's finest, I've seen my best friend crushed under the treads of a fearsome Panzer III.

I have witnessed the mass executions of my people at Bridges.

I've stood my ground, helpless to save my comrades as we are pinned down by suppressing fire from an MG-42.

War is truly hell.

Yet even now, as I cower in my frozen foxhole praying that the next artillery shell doesn't land on my head... even as I pray that some day I will make it home to see my beautiful wife or witness my son who is now old enough to walk...

I gather myself. I am one of Russia's finest. I pick up my faithful mosin, load the last two cartridges into the chamber, adjust my bayonet, and charge into the smoke.


Seriously. This game has given me PTSD. I dream about the horrors of war and watch my friends die every night. I want my mommy

Buy it.

reviewText:
This game is not your typical FPS game. Hardcore modes is punishing wherein one shot one kill can happen a lot of times. Forget your COD skills that will not work on this game. Some word of advice for new players:
1. Don't run and Gun
2. listen to your Squad Leaders
3. Team Leader is vital to winning, if you can't do it let others take the position
4. Riflemen are expendable but if you die a lot, your team is gonna drain its tickets.
5. Snipers focus on enemy MGs and Squad Leaders
6. Squad Leaders should mark enemy spawn points for artillery and lay down once you've done it. You are a walking spawn point, spawn your squad to capture enemy territory.

reviewText:
The following review is for Red Orchestra 2 and Rising Storm. (both included when buying Rising Storm)

Red Orchestra 2 and its stand-alone expansion Rising Storm are World War II military First-person shooters with an emphasis on solid gameplay mechanics and gritty authenticity. While the two differ in gameplay, both are grounded in realism without being marred by unnecessary clunkiness. Both were developed by Tripwire Interactive, the studio that is probably best known for Killing Floor and the original Red Orchestra game. Much like Killing Floor, these games shine most in the way that they feature what are quite possibly the best shooting mechanics that you will find in any video game.

These games are by no means dead" as some doom-and-gloom internet posters would have you beleive. Despite featuring a complex set of controls and being fairly unforgiving about deaths in multiplayer
date: the games do a great job of expressing that the multiplayer expirience is hard but fair. Perceptivness
hoursPlayed:
and team communication are always heavily rewarding for players willing to go the extra mile.

Much of the early criticism for Red Orchestra 2 by popular review sources and Metacritic mainly focus on the game's rough state at launch rather than the game you will be playing today. RO2 and RS have been greatly improved with the help of official patches and updates and even moreso with the help of the player community that is the backbone of the series.

Rising Storm offers a new and different expirience to that of Red Orchestra 2. While still featuring the original game's brutality and satisfying gun mechanics
voteText:
rising storm features more asymetrical gameplay that is more rooted in fast-paced action than the base game. This stand-alone expansion is great for both veterans looking for something fun and different as well as new players that felt intimidated by the heavily punishing nature of RO2's multiplayer. Upon purchasing Rising Storm players will recieve a copy of Red Orchestra 2 if they do not already own it. Red Orchestra 2 owners will be able to play a limited version of Rising Storm and will also recieve a discount when buying the expansion.

These games are great for anyone looking for a First-Person shooter with solid gameplay mechanics. Red Orchestra 2 and Rising storm offer a great experience that rivals and even surpasses those offered by AAA FPS titles.*


*The games are to be appreciated on their own merits rather than to be used to boost one's own ego for not being part of the Call of Duty or Battlefield audience."

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/HPpvwJdN9iQ
Game: Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad
Genre: Multiplayer First-person Shooter
Developer: Tripwire Interactive
Publisher: Tripwire Interactive
Copy supplied by Steam

Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad is a multiplayer first-person shooter set in World War II developed and published by Tripwire Interactive.

STORYThe main game is set during the invasion of Russia from the Nazis against the Soviets. There is also a standalone game called Rising Storm that features the American attacks against the Japanese after Pearl Harbor. The game doesn't have a real storyline, but the setting feels very grounded in history and there are plenty of real life locations, as well as actual guns and vehicles from the era.

GRAPHICSThe game uses Unreal Engine 3. There are your usual texture pop-ins and small performance hiccups, even though there aren't as many as usual. The game olds up fairly well and the decaying cities of Russia are well varied and full of little details that suck you into the experience.

GAMEPLAYThe game features a variety of modes, including Territory (where you conquer different places on a map), Firefight (team deathmatch), and a Multiplayer Campaign (which is basically Territory played on multiple levels and stages). The levels are all very well balanced, and both sides feel equally as powerful. The game lacks a crosshair and an ammo count: while it is pretty weird at first, you slowly start seeing that it's the best way to get sucked into the game.
There are multiple classes to choose from, each one with its set of items and weapons to use on the battlefield, but in the end the game rewards the most skilled players, and there isn't a weapon more powerful than another: they are all balanced to suite each player to their favourite play style without making them too overpowered. The Squad Leaders work as spawn points, while the Commander has the ability to force respawn and to select sections of the territory to launch an artillery attack or bombardments.
I have never felt more paranoid in a game than when playing RO2: whenever you are getting shot at, you lose focus, your vision gets blurry, and you start losing the ability to hear. When crawling through the battlefield with a bunch of comrades, seeing one of the suddenly become a ragdoll fills you with fear of knowing that a sniper is probably loading the next bullet to send to your brain. This are just some of the amazing experiences I've had in this game that in my opinion shows how brutal and unheroic war is: people die, people scream, and in the end each side loses a ton of good soldiers.

CHALLENGEThe game features bullet drops and realistic damage: shooting at someone's leg will make him limp, shooting at his lungs will make him grasp for air for a couple of seconds without collapsing... When I started replaying the game for this review, I remembered how unforgiving it is for new players. But if you give it enough time, you will get better at handling weapons and calculating the difference bullet drops as well as the best tactics to win on both sides. It becomes a very rewarding game.

SOUNDThe sound is phenomenal, with realistic weapon effects, cheesy but fun voice acting and powerful explosions. The soundtrack is also very underrated, and it homages classic themes from movies like Saving Private Ryan.

REPLAYABILITYThe game is constantly being updated by the developers, and the community is pretty great too: many maps and modes can be downloaded from the Workshop to change the game's formula up. There are also over 140 Steam achievements that will keep you hooked for a long time.

Overall, Red Orchestra 2 is one of my favourite multiplayer games of all time, as well as a great war game that requires a bit of tactics and good skills. Everyone who enjoys online games and first person shooters as well as more skills than luck will have a blast playing this hard at first but hugely satisfying game.

Story: n/a
Graphics: 8.5
Gameplay: 9.5
Challenge: 9
Sound: 9.5
Replayability: 9

ENJOYMENT: 9
FRUSTRATION: 7.5

reviewText:
Combat Report for HQ
Codename: Operation Stalemate II

Veteran class Squad leader #2, DidHeDied
Time of operation: 8:32am, September 15th, 1944

Clear weather, humidity and temperature both high.
Our commander (Dr. Steve Brule) has tasked squad #2 with taking objective Bravo on the airbase beach island of Peleliu.
Near unacceptable casualties expected.
8:45am, we land and begin our assault on the airfield. I smack hotkey 6 for my binoculars, and get an artillery mark for Commander Brule.
But our Commander was not at the radio... He was solo charging the enemy line (smoke grenade in hand) and singing backstreet boys are back on public voice comms; with overwhelming gusto.

I later found out this is called “psychological warfare”

At first the enemy couldn’t believe what this American was doing and were hesitant to shoot, Commander brule then ran back to the battalion radio after laying down a smoke screen for squad #2.
He then gave his orders “Wait for the first 3 salvos of artillery, then we ♥♥♥♥ them like a warm cherry pie boys!”
I count the salvos and keep my squad in check, on the start of the 4th salvo I let out a piercing battle cry over team voice comms; and we begin our charge over no man's land.
9:15am, squad #2 advanced into and took the enemy trenches of objective Bravo.

During our assault we took 3 casualties to type 99 MG's: LulzBoy69, Drunkenballsack and MustyGooch, may their souls rest in peace (for the next 8 seconds, 7 seconds, 6 seconds, FORCE RESPAWN BY DR. STEVE BRULE).

Squad #2 fought valiantly for the next few points, we had a brave flamer lead the charge, and riflemen follow, with our MG’s dishing out relentless amounts of lead suppression on the enemy positions.

♥♥♥♥ I have to go now, I don’t have time to finish my report.
I am only allowed 10 minutes of computer. Now I have to put on the jacket that stops my arms from moving and go back to my room.
My room has soft walls, it is nice, but it gets a bit lonely sometimes.
You’ll probably get to join me here if you buy the game, yay I can’t wait to see you!

reviewText:
Open the game for the first time in months, join the biggest server.

It's a Rising storm expansion, Japan vs USA.

I join USA.

We fight, hard. Our flamethrowers burn them out of the brush and push them back to their home camp.

They are dug in, hard. Anyone who charges in gets mowed down by mg fire.

I try to flank the camp, get sniped when I approach within 100 meters.

I spawn as a machine gunner and setup behind a burnt truck ~300 meters away.

Dial in my sights

I'm ready.

I lay down surpessing fire, scream in my mic for us to charge.

No response, but my teammates eventually take the base and we win, but I die repeatedly by japanese snipers.

I look at the scoreboard.

I'm 0-32

I was the only non-ai player in the whole server.

10/10 would die 32 times to secure US victory again.

reviewText:
Fantastic game that offers a high level of detail, innovation and options. RO2 offers a challenging, yet rewarding, style of gameplay. True you will get picked off countless times as you bumble around the map but once your survival instinct kicks in and you pull of that 150m headshot with your trusty bolt action there is no kill in any game quite like it.

And although the game had a rocky start the developers have, for the most part, listened to the community. The game continues to grow and improve with a large update containing tonnes of free content just on the horizon.

If you are looking to purchase Red Orchestra 2 get the Rising Storm expansion as it RO2 comes with it (and you save yourself a few pounds/euros/dollars/yen).

reviewText:
It was a wet, cold night when I picked this game up on sale. I downloaded the essentials and got into it.
I did the tutorial and went into my first match. Wanting to become the ultimate camper, I went Russian Marksman, armed with nothing but a PU Mosin-Nagant and a revolver that can't do anything after 5 m.

Along with my comrades, I softened up the German defences, and my comrades and I pulled off a daring charge and took the bridge. We got to the other side, but were pinned down by an MG nest set up on a lumber pile and were forced to take cover with what we could find. I quickly ran into the forest, attempting to flank our main obstacle. The bristling fire of the MG-34 stood out from the sounds of the other weapons incessantly being discharged at both sides. Non-stop, this cutting sound of the MG-34 and the dying screams of my comrades made me even more determined to kill this machinegunner. I managed to get into point blank range. I wanted to humiliate him and go down in history as that guy who melee'd that dude who killed 20 people. He saw me.

He turned to me, ready to empty what ammo he had left in my tan-coloured clothes and Soviet body. He was about to fire... and a click was heard. He didn't have any more ammo. He didn't even attempt to take out his pistol. He looked at me, and I shot him. I distinctly remember his body jittering. A pool of blood assembled around him, and the jittering stopped. Then I bolted my weapon, and carried on.

Welcome to Red Orchestra 2: PTSD Edition.

The game itself, a multiplayer-based WW2 tactical shooter is based around the Eastern Front of WW2, particularly the Battle of Stalingrad. Picking up the game, you will be thrown into  the most realistic depiction of war since the original Medal of Honor. You want a gun? Here you go. Now go and take that objective, soldier! The game throws you into the mud without any other expectations other than victory and woe to the vanquished. You are to fight! You are to kill! You are to die! You are to wait 20 seconds just to be mindlessly thrown into this slow-paced, massive battle of up to 64 players and you will enjoy it! A learning curve is prevalent in the game, as it isn't a run of the mill FPS. A couple hours in the singleplayer, or on a bot practice match should be enough to get you used to the odd way the game handles.

The graphics are very pretty and rather easy to run, which is sad when you think of it because the folks over at Tripwire wanted you to have as traumatizing experience as humanly possible.

10/10 would have PTSD again

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 / Rising Storm is an amazing game.

While most shooters these days are fast paced , this game does not go down that path. This is a good thing , in my opinion. Rather than run around and shoot people to try to get to the top of the Leaderboards , this game is about working with your team , to complete a certain objective.

The game is extremely realistic.

You feel like you are actually in the game. Hearing the bullets whizzing by overhead , the screams of pain of dying men and mortar explosions going off in the distance help to immerse you into the game.

The graphics are also pretty damn good, the maps look great.

A very unique game.

Definately pick up this game if you want a realistic , team based first person shooter.

9/10 , my FPS GOTY
voteText: 29 of 35 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Hi, Billy Mays here

Are you looking for a realistic, gritty, brutal and immersive world war II multiplayer fps? Have you always wondered what it felt like to have your skin melt off your bones as a stream of fire roasts your body? Do you wish to feel the satisfaction of hitting a running target - 300 meters away - right in the head? Have you always wanted to hold a katana in your hands and charge with your team at an unsuspecting American battalion?
Well look no further, because this game answers your call!

Rising storm is a very realistic multiplayer fps, with battles up to 64 people. The game is set in World war II, in the Pacific theatre, involving the United states and the Japanese. Battles are extremely intense, and teamwork and tactics play as a key contributor in winning battles. Most battles in rising storm involve the opposing team starting off at one end of the map and capturing or destorying key points, trying to advance forward, while you hold them back and defend them or vice versa. Teams are normally fixed in these scenarios (meaning one team is always going to be the attacker and the other defender).  The balancing in this game is very different from those in other games. Asymmetrical is the term. The Japanese, while having inferior weapons, have much more higher supression resistance and higher morale Aka balls made of titanum or some ♥♥♥♥, compared to the Americans, who have frequent panic attacks. Sly little booby traps can be layed by the Japanese, also and you can get all of your mates to do a banzai charge (good times). However what the Americans DO have is the bigger guns, more load, heavy firepower and Macca's meaning they can use their superior technology to their advantage.

Moving onto maps - Their designed almost perfectly. The maps are large and spacious without having loads of empty space and everything is placed in the right spot without being obvious. Every map is played differently too, for example 'Hanto' which is a dense jungle type area makes it very difficult for the Americans to spot the heavily camouflaged Japanese. Another map called Iwo Jima has an uphill slant with many concealed bunkers to defend from, which can ridden with booby traps. All in all the maps in this game is what balances the teams out the most.

Rising storm has some really decent graphics. The gun models are astounding and realistic, and textures for character models are very good, too. Environments look gritty and worn out without being too dark and unrealistic. Overall its actually very, very decent. Audio in this game is great as well. It really does add suspense and fully immerses. No silly background sound effects, everything is being produced real time. The music is suprisingly very well done, and doesnt get in the way or break the immersion of a battle.

The game may be very, very difficult to get used to for most people. Controls, character movement and coordination may feel clunky for some people as the weapon is not fixed to the center of the screen and the character gains speed instead of instantly moving. Many beginners will also find it difficult to tell the difference between their own fellow team members and the enemy and will shoot without confirming. It takes a while to get to know how each map works out and what the objectives are. In the end though, once you do get used to it you'll be satisfied.

Lastly, communication is key in this game. Although a team may be able to capture a point or even win the round without communicating, it will most likely be very difficult as people will be scattered, unsure of when to attack and generally go off and do their own thing. So whoop out your mic and help out the team or if not, atleast take the time to learn which button you press to chat. If you're looking for a more casual experience, use a general role instead of a special class.


You get 2 games for the  price of 19 bucks (USD), which is Rising storm and Red orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad bundled together. I probably shouldnt tell you about the download size. Happy Friday.

Being used to playing CS, my first few games were utter confusion. I couldn't distinguish friends from enemies, I just can't aim fire and run at the same time. Run into an enemy face to face  when you turn a corner? Good luck getting that shot in while your mind just blanks out.

My first ever thought when playing the game was Why is everyone running?".  Where are they going? It was just utter confusion.

But after a few hours

reviewText:
One of the few First Person Shooter (FPS) games that I have played that have a steep enough learning curve for it to remain challenging, but not overly steep that anyone can't play and have fun.
I have put 56 hours into the game at the time of writing this review, and even I am still the 'newbie', I feel like I have lots to still learn about the way everything works in this game, but that is part of the fun.

Red Orchestra 2/ Rising Storm is extremely tactical, you cannot just go running blindly around the map without expecting a bullet to the chest. You need to inspect the map, hide behind the cover of smoke as you make your progression towards the objective.
I had never had as much fun in a WW2 shooter since my Medal of Honor Allied Assualt multiplayer days, the music is extremely atmospheric and I love running in a zig-zag in open towards some cover and bullet spring off the dirt around you making your vision go blurry.

If you are looking for a game with a great community, great atmosphere and challenging but rewarding gameplay. Get this.

See you on the battlefield, soldier.

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 is simply one of the finest if not the greatest WW2 game that has hit the market to date, and there are numerous features that make this game sine in almost every aspect to back this statement up.
First of all the graphics.When maxed out on the ultra graphics i dare say this game looks as realistic as a game can look and can compete even with the graphics of games such as Battlefield.In addition all the maps are geniously desinged so as both team work and tactical thinking are needed in order for a team to progress while at the same time maintening a balance between the 2 sides.
This also brings me to the next key aspect of the game that makes it so appealing to me ,which is TEAMWORK and i simply can not strech this enough.Forget about all your call of duties and battlefields and such where all you need for the victory is one effective player.In this game if teamwork is not utilized defeat is inevitable.Even the slightest hindering in a teams teamwork such as for example a gunner that doesnt know where to place his mg to provide supressing fire can mean the deference between a point captured and a point lost.And to back this importance of teamwork a finite amount of classes are being introduced ,each one utilizing different guns and equipment for different purposes.In addition each gun comes with up to 3 REALISTIC attachments that can be obtained through the extensive use of the gun.These attachments can vary and are all historically accurate in contrast to the ones in game such as call of duty (for example there's no apperture sight for the mp40,an attachment clearly completly fictional).
Moreover the games realistic feel is further increased by certain aspects that the HUD and the gun mechanics have.For the first time in the history of gaming there is no bullet counter and instead the player can have a rough guess of how many bullets he has left by quicly releasing and weighting his mag or by extracting his bolt half way to have a look at the clip if he is using a rifle.Most guns are also usually 1 shot kill if a player lands a headshot,a heartshot,a nutshot or an upertorso shot.If the player doesnt land one of these shots the player he hit will become wounded and will have to bandge immediatly if he wishes not to bleed out.Therefore the chances that you will hit and enemy and he will either kill you or run away are very few ,as they should in my opinion.The game also uses a realistic ballistic system accounting for gravity and such,and it is for that reason that the ability is given to the player to ajust his sights for the proper range.Actions availiable to the player such as changing barrels of an overheated mg,aiming through the iron sights of a snipe rifle and changing through the rate of certain machineguns also add to the realism.
Tank combat is furthermore a feature that sines in this game.Never before has the intirior of a tank looked so realistic in a game and never before have the correct seats within a tank been utilized correctly.In order for the tank to be used to its full potential, the gunner, the driver,the tank commander and the mg gunner will have to work together.
Last but not least a feature that i just love and think every game should have is that when the server is not full of players ,bots take the empty slots.In this way even if only 2 players are palying on a server the game wont feel empty and dead.I must however in account of fairness admit that the AI for the bots is nothing to be really proud of as they will often stay in the spawn running back and forth,stuck in various places or wont advance as the match progresses.I have met this bugs however only a handfull of times and i also have to say that they are not so game breaking as they sound,plus when the server has 56 bots 2 or 3 stuck or glitched isnt really a big deal.I have faith that Tripwire Interactive will adress this issue in a future patch however and so i do not count it as minus for this review.

To conclude Red Orchestra Heroes of Stalingrad is game that can be charectarized as realistic,graphicly immersive and thought provoking as it requires the player to strategically work with his teammates to achieve victory.It has only 1 minor issue that can be easily adressed in a later patch and is made by a company that is known to maintain its games freshness through patches,updates ,contests etc.It is a game with a staggering amount of inovative features and is sure not to disapoint you ,as long as you are not a casul 13 year old cod-loving tryhard.If I were to rate it I would definetly give it a 11/10.I hope this review has helped you and that i will see you online playing this marvel of a game.

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 is the best murder simulator I've ever played. It's not the best first-person shooter or multiplayer game, or even the best team-based multiplayer game. It's certainly not the best World War II game, and its singleplayer is the worst I've played in years. But in the killing, and in the being killed, RO2 is a terrifying and satisfying experience.

You're a soldier in either Germany's or USSR's army. You've got your back against the wall in a room with one door, two windows and three walls, and you're peeking around a corner into the exposed core of a half-destroyed building. Every room could conceal an enemy soldier, and you've died a hundred times already, always from that one angle you didn't check.

Looking down through the rubble, you see an enemy soldier break from behind a wall. You aim and fire in a single motion. You've shot him and now he's dead. It's exactly like a million other games, but it feels nothing like any other game. It's the little things that make the difference, such as the sound of your own breathing when you lifted the rifle to your face, and the way it bobbed slightly in your hands. It's in the mark on your enemy's chest where the bullet hit, and the way his blood spritzed from his back, marking that bullet's exit. It's in the way he fell, forced by some terrible weight. Sometimes, but not this time, it would be the way he clutches his stomach, yelling in Russian, or the way he fires his machinegun madly during his last few seconds of life.

At some point, the developers of Red Orchestra 2 realised that if the primary interaction in your game is killing, then you should probably make the killing feel incredible. It's this attention to detail that turns an otherwise ordinary game, a slightly more realistic Battlefield, into something great, with Soviets fighting Nazis across mother Russia.

While the weapons feel remarkable, the classes that carry them are familiar. There's the Assault class, with a sub-machinegun; the Marksman, with a sniper rifle; the Rifleman and Elite Rifleman; and a few others. The few inventive classes, such as Squad Leaders and Commanders, do little to change the flow of battle. Both roles have valuable abilities, but several people follows orders on public servers. My favorite is the Squad Leader.

Even tanks don't add much to the experience. They require a whole different set of skills to use well, and have lovingly detailed interiors, but they are an easily ignored nuisance on the few maps that actually include them. On any server I've ever joined, the one tank-only map is the moment in the war when everyone disappears to write letters home to their mothers.

It's creeping through the ruined buildings of Pavlov's House, one of the best maps, and jumping every time you see a piece of paper float through the air. It's listening to the footsteps echoing through the building, and freezing as you hear creaking on the stairs. It's the time I rounded a corner to come face to face with a Nazi holding a grenade above his head, bayoneted him in the stomach, and then dived down some stairs to escape the blast. It's the thrill of sprinting across an open field, enemy machinegun fire whizzing all around you.

Death in RO2 is so sudden and violent that you're constantly on edge, an experience that's exacerbated by all the little pieces of information the game is keeping from you.

Firstly, at a distance there's no easy, instant way to tell if a soldier is on your side. The uniforms are distinct, but not the fluorescent green cycling jackets you need on a smoky battlefield. If you're close to someone, looking at them, and they're on your side, their name will appear, but often you don't have that kind of time.

Secondly, there's no instant kill confirmation. You'll be fighting across the ruined tenements on the wonderful Pavlov's House map, and you'll spot a head in a window across the street. From the shape of the helmet, you'll infer that it's an enemy and fire. The head will disappear from view. Are they dead? Did you miss? Are they wounded and bandaging themselves? Is it safe to move on? You can only hope. Wherever it can, RO2 makes murky what other games want to be clear. There's no ammo display on the HUD; you have to check the barrel for a rough estimate, or count your own shots. Realism mode, which is activated on roughly half of the servers currently running, removes certainty altogether by taking out friendly names, kill confirmations and the radar. It doesn't make a huge difference, but I had more fun in non-realism mode.

Lastly, the heart-munching adrenaline you feel in front of your PC is mirrored in the soldier you're controlling. When you're stood at a window and bullets start to chip against the frame, all the colour drains from the screen, the world blurs, and your aim becomes worse than a drunk man. You need to get out of there to catch your breath.

reviewText: My freshly recruited japanese rifleman found himself defending a 2-story building on the island of Saipan from the filthy american gaijin with his fellow imperial bretheren. He had shot 4 brave Marines who attempted to climb the rubble into his squads fighting position, with all of them screaming in agony or choking on their blood until they died. After the 4th traumatic incident his rifle's magazine ran empty. As my poor, depressed soldier sat there reloading his rifle with broken morale from an artillery strike, a lone American charged the rubble, but this was no ordinary Marine. Soon a wall of flame engulfed the lone assualt troop at the top of the rubble, who was the only other man defending the entrance. The hose of fire then quickly spread to his fellow soldiers guarding the windows,  with my now-lonely rifleman looking on in terror as his bretheren attempted in vain to put out the fires, screaming in agony the entire time. They were all helplessely burned to a crisp before his eyes just as he had finished reloading. With the will of the Emperor in him, he took aim at the lone American who had just slaughtered so many of his own, but as he brought the rifle up a stream of rounds from a squad leader's Thompson tore into his throat, causing him to choke on his own blood. With his last, gurgled breath, he watched the now victorius Americans securing the position.\n\n.45 ACP/10 would get PTSD again

reviewText: I'd like to start off by saying that I did not enjoy this game, however I don't intend to discourage people from playing it simply because I wasn't entertained, especially now when you can get the game for free. Red Orchestra 2 is a fickle monster. On the one hand, the innovative gameplay and close attention to realism and detail give this release tons of potential. Unfortunately, the amount old-fashioned quirks coupled with the most clueless AI I've seen in a while takes away a lot from what this game has to offer.If you strip the game's uninspired visuals and interface and manage to come past its bugs and glitches, Red Orchestra 2 takes no prisoners with its realistic mechanics and physics. It is a game for a hardcore PC audience who thrive on this type of games with its relatively slow-paced tempo yet high intensity.An immensely ambitious game, and in some ways, it's even a groundbreaking one. However, its focus on realism will turn off fans of arcade shooters. If you think both Battlefield and Call of Duty are too exaggerated and unrealistic, and feel Counter-Strike is too soft, Red Orchestra 2 might be the game for you. It doesn't appeal to me, though.

reviewText:
Forget about being a hero:

War is about survival, following orders. Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad (Rising Storm too btw) captures this very same feeling to the perfection. Forget about running on the field and firing two machine guns akimbo like Rambo. You're a soldier, russian or german, american or japanese. The fight will always seem unfair and it is: get over it. Then how can you win and enjoy you may ask? Keep your head down, take cover, watch out for your teammates, follow your commander's orders, go for the objectives: be a soldier. The slightest misstep can kill you and your teammates. And if you win the battle, always remember that you would never have made it without your team, your squad leader and your commander.

Footmen win wars, but don't get credit:

More often then you'd want, you will have the role of a lousy footman, a bolt action rifle and 2 grenades. That is it, but you must make the best out of it. And if you do well enough, you'll have the opportunity to get promoted: sniper, automatic rifle, anti-tank or even tank crewmember. Don't worry, this game is hard at first, but always try your best, take time, don't rush things.

A pearl is always difficult to acquire:

This game is hard because it is different. It requires patience and strategy. It may seem hard and it can be frustrating. But trust me, if you want to see what war really is, i think Red Orchestra 2 gives a decent vision of that.

reviewText: The best FPS ever made in my opinion. reviewText:
Today I will be reviewing a video game called Red Orchestra 2. The game was developed by Treyarch (The same people responsible for such classics as : The Great Gatsby, A Clockwork Orange and Super Mario Brothers) and published by Ubisoft.

Let's talk a bit about the game :
The game takes place in a post apocalyptic Paris in the year 2250. When the game begins, you can see society rebuilding itself all around you. Society has been split into 2 sides : The neo-nazis and the capitalists. The neo-nazis are a group led by Adolf Hitler's brain which was recovered by the Illuminati from the very same bunker where Hitler commited suicide. The second group is led by Rndrew Ayan. He is a curious Lovecraft inspired repairman, whose seeking to bring Paris back to it's former glory through any means necessary. The game offers you two ways to play, join the nazis in their quest to take over Paris for the Führer or join the capitalists to restore things to the way they were. The story is amazing. One minute I found myself laughing at the obscure situations that the capitalist soldiers found themselves in, the next I was crying when they lost the Eiffel tower because Sgt. Johnson (Who is a key character in the Capitalist campaign) wanted to send a telegram to his wife back in Austria who was missing him dearly.

Let's talk about the game's mechanics next :
The game is presented in a 2D Bird's Eye perspective, at first I thought this was odd, however it becomes apparent that this was the directors vision and the game is perfect as is. One of they key mechanics of the game is the point'n'click-esque interface, featuring options such as : Insult"
recommended: "Shoot" and "Heil". Characters in the game react to your every move
hoursPlayed: from simply moving around to doing key story changing events such as demolishing the Eiffel tower ( which is entirely optional ). The game blends the 2D
voteText: Run and gun
helpfulPercent: Romance
votesHelpful: Adventure and Puzzle game elements within it seamlessly to create a unique experience the likes of which will probably never be bested.\n\nMove over Call of Duty Ghosts
votesTotal: Medal of Honor Warfighter and Battlefield 4. There's a new king in town and his name is Red Orchestra 2.\n\n10/10"

reviewText:
I've never played a tactical team play game that grants the flexibility, the complexity, and the amount of realism that Red Orchestra 2 brings. I can't think of any parallel that comes close. That alone should say a lot if you're looking to buy the game. In short, it's worth every dollar even at regular price, but for any game, I still say wait for the sale. This game hits sale price a lot.

Now, I'm not saying this game is perfect. It has a few negatives which I'll cover but take the negatives with a grain of salt. The positives within this game far outweigh the negatives.

I'll start with the negatives, the integrated Cover system" is broken in some ways. It doesn't entirely keep you in cover. I find
date: players who use the Cover system easier to kill behind cover. This is because
recommended: the animation your character goes into when using integrated covering leaves your character's head and back exposed to fire at modest angles. And by modest
hoursPlayed: I mean an enemy won't have to move much to kill you in the integrated cover system. I turned my auto-cover button off by unbinding the key associated with it under Game Options. If I want to use cover
voteText: I do it myself without the integrated system.\n\nThat's honestly the only negative I give this game. The rest is good news in terms of how much I enjoyed this game for challenge and reward. You'll find after several hours or several dozen hours that this game has very extensive experience system. Guns gather experience
helpfulPercent: classes gather experience
votesHelpful: and your character level gathers experience. The experience system is not just a number
votesTotal: higher levels grants suppression resistances
votesFunny: stamina buffs
commentsCount: and accuracy buffs. These buffs become quite helpful at higher levels. Guns that gather experience will gain tiers
column16: each gun has a maximum level of 50 and there are 3 tiers associated with it. Each gun gets tier 1 by default
column17: tier 2 is unlocked at level 25 and tier 3 is unlocked at level 50. Depending on what gun you have
column18: tier 2 and tier 3 will have unlocked attachments for the gun like long-range sights and bayonets or extended magazines. This system is very grindy however
column19: since there are so many guns to level. If you're a completionist like me
column20: getting every gun to level 50 will take a very long time.\n\nThere are a wide variety of historical guns for all four nations. Each gun has better uses than others
column21: it's up to the user to decide which gun you like most. Majority of players will say PPSH-41 is the weapon of choice
column22: while others will counter that the MG42 and Mkb 42 are better. It's a constant daily argument. I personally like all the guns
column23: even the bolt action rifles. In a full 64-player game
column24: I was able to get MVP using only a rifleman class with a bolt action rifle. It depends on how well you want to perform.\n\nThere are vehicles
column25: there are medium tanks
column26: light tanks and troop transports. Medium tanks and light tanks get their own classes and are effective but not over-powered. An experienced tank driver can cause a lot of headache
column28: an experienced anti-tank gunner can take out a tank with a single well placed shot at the tank's ammo rack.\n\nBeing Commander is a lot of fun but also actually requires a lot of hands-on command skills. Commander's job is basically to sit at the radio and call in artillery or recon. Commander can also force-respawn players waiting to respawn. Giving orders is important
column29: not only are you telling your team where to go. Players within the area of your order get +1 points for each kill and capturing objectives as a result of your order. Additionally
column30: AI actually follow Commander orders. Sending 30 or so AI into a single base is quite funny.\n\nThe AI is not the smartest nor the worst... It's difficult to describe the AI
column31: they're amazing and terrible at the same time. Sometimes you can stand in front of an AI and it won't shoot you or it will miss you a dozen times. And on the other hand
column32: AI are known to do 180 no-scope headshots. It's up to you to decide on this one.\n\nIt's almost nearly impossible to notice for new players so I will point it out now. There is bullet drop. But bullet drop is not noticeable until you are about 200m away from your target. But that is rare
column33: majority of the time you will be shooting within 170m on average and a lot of close quarters right down to melee combat. In all my hours of playing this game
column34:
I have only had to change my sight range to 200m for only one kill.

Pros:Wide variety of maps and gamemodes. (Best gamemode imo is Campaign)
Large selection of weapons.
Extensive experience system that rewards at new levels.
A lot of active communities and it's easy to find a full 64-man server. (I find full servers daily as of this review.)
Realistic combat. (Realism-mode adds to this and it's the only mode I play. It's kind of this game's 'hardcore mode.')
Tanks and transports are not OP.
User-friendly command system.
Artillery adds zest to an already pleasant experience.
Workshop is available for custom maps and mods.
Single-player AI battles in Workshop. (I still prefer playing against players.)Cons:Can be unforgiving for new players. You will die a lot.
Broken "Cover System."
Tanks are easy to get stuck.Neutral:Mkb 42 and MG42 gunshot sound effects are too loud. (my own opinion
column35: however.)\nAI is both amazing and terrible.\nStamina is low and gun handling is terrible for new players. (all fixed via gaining levels)Overall
column36: I highly recommend this game. It took me away from Battlefield 4

reviewText:
(English isn't my first language...you've been warned! ;)
I've been planing to do a RO2 review for quite some time now, but never really got around to do it...until now! This review might not be perfect or complete. But these are my thoughts about the game and yeah...here we go.

As you might have guessed from the game's title, this fps takes place during WW2. There are two parts of it: vanilla RO2 on the european eastern front, where you fight as either Germany or the Soviet Union(goodies: tanks/vehicles, OOORAAAH!), and the pacific theatre of war expansion Rising Storm (goodies: flamethrowers/katanas, Baaanzaaaii!).

Beware though: as RO2 is primarily a multiplayer title, the AI in both SP and MP is rather...sub optimal. It sucks.

Therefore, instead of buying Heroes of Stalingrad for the SP content like a friggin ♥♥♥♥♥ (like me...), I HIGHLY recommend buying the Rsising Storm expansion, as it also happens to have ALL Heroes of Stalingrad MP maps so...yeah. No brainer :)

But now! Enough with the theoretical nonsense and onto the ACTION! Huuza!
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=251945579
RO2 imo fills a very interesting niche between games like CoD (fast paced, very arcady FPS) and games like Arma 3 (veeery slow paced, big focus on realismn).
Keep in mind: I realise there are more games out there than just these two, I only picked them as represantatives of two very different game design philosophies.
So RO2 might be the perfect game for people who find CoD to be too much of the arcady bull**** it is (please excuse my Frensh here, but I really fu***** hate CoD) and Arma 3 to be too much...well, just too much. RO2 is still fast paced...you rarely ever have to walk more then 30 seconds to come within enemy contact, but one bullet can still drop you.
Other features for example are a suppresion system which makes your aim go all over the place if somebody shoots you a lot as well as weapon unlocks/improvements for all classes/weapons.

reviewText:
One of the best FPS games of the last couple of years. The gameplay offers the perfect blend between fast paced action (because of respawn waves) and realism.

I cannot think of a better WW2 infantry (and tanking) game. The depth and detail in the game are amazing. Correct weaponry and classes guarantee an immersive environment.

The community is one of the best ones out there, if you play on the more popular servers teamwork is usually guaranteed as people try to communicate and cooperate actively.

All in all, you cannot go wrong with this title!

reviewText:
Lobster with mango is often found on French menus and is served here with a citrusy salad and butter sauce.
Ingredients

For the orange zest salad

½ orange, zest removed and cut into very fine strips, flesh segmented

250g/9oz mixed salad leaves (such as rocket, frissée, watercress, nasturtium or dandelion)

2 tbsp sugar

1 tbsp Moscatel vinegar

2 tbsp rapeseed oil

For the lobster and mango

1x 550g/1lb 4oz precooked lobster

100g/3½oz butter

salt

1 lemon, juice only

1 mango, peeled, stoned and sliced

mustard cress, to garnish

Preparation method

For the orange zest salad, blanch the strips of zest in boiling water three times to remove the bitterness. Drain the zest thoroughly and set aside on kitchen paper.

Mix the salad leaves with the orange segments. Set aside.

For the lobster and mango, blanch the lobster in boiling salted water, two minutes for the tails and three minutes for the claws.

Remove the lobster meat from the shells, cut the tail in half and remove the claws.

In a pan, warm the butter until foaming, drop in the lobster and heat through, basting all the time. Season, to taste, with salt and lemon juice.

Remove the lobster from the pan and add the mango slices to the butter. Cook until the mango is soft and warm. Reserve the butter.

For the orange zest salad, place the zest in a small frying pan with the sugar. Heat until the sugar is caramelised and coats the zest. Set aside to cool slightly, them mix with the vinegar and oil. Pour over the salad leaves and toss to coat.

Place the dressed salad in the centre of serving plates with the lobster around the side and mango on top. Drizzle the butter over and garnish with mustard cress.

reviewText:
So I'll avoid another review and instead offer advice for noobs where they're likely to read it.

The community is generally welcoming but providing you follow two easy rules.

1. Do NOT take the Team Leader position.
2. Do NOT take a Squad Leader position.

OK, 4 rules.

3. Do NOT play this like COD.
4. Shout out that you're new and ask for advice. Many of us like to show off our experience so will gladly help when asked.

Red Orchestra is a team game, played over a number of battles in a campaign (usually). A TEAM game. As an example, if you're a points ♥♥♥♥♥, the top of the leader board is the person with the most TEAM points. NOT highest number of kills. Team points can win games.

The issue with those two roles, TL and SL, is they have to be played properly if the team is to win. And TL, and preferably SL's, need a microphone and experience.

So thats it. Do not got TL or SL  until you have a lot of experience OR .. you're willing to tell the team you are new and want advice. Then listen and follow.

Also be aware of the role you pick or are allocated.

MG's usually move to the flanks and provide cross covering fire. Keeping the enemies heads low. Accuracy and kills is actually less important than scaring the enemy. Make them keep their heads down. When you get low on Ammo shout out using your command keys .. ask for ammo and riflemen should bring it to you.

Snipers .. your job is to take out enemy MG's and Squad Leaders. Anyone else is just going to give your position away for little benefit.

Tanks ... always operate best with a crew who communicate with microphones. Use the 6 key to swap between shell types. AP for armour, HE for everything else. Remember that you have 2 mgs. One in the hull, one parrallel with the main gun. commander, stay inside the tank. You are an easy target.  Driver, hatch closed.

SL's, including Tank SL. You have 5 jobs. Do them and your team might win.
1. Stay alive. DO NOT DIE. DO NOT BE A HERO. If you want points, do your job. You can get to the top of the leader board without firing a round.
2. Mark artillery targets. If attacking, locate it just past a cap, preventing the enemy from entering. If defending, in a position in the cap furthest away from you .. ie where they enter the cap.  There are many variations of this on the different maps. Learn them. Always be thinking ahead to the next cap point and try to get your marks in early so your TL isn't waiting. You get team points for any enemy killed by artillery.
3. You are a mobile spawn point for your squad. Get close to the cap and stay down. Stay alive. Your squad can spawn next to you rather than all the way back at the previous spawn. this enable syou to quickly cap and advance.
4. Smoke.  You start with one smoke and can pick a second at the nearest ammo point. Use it to keep your squad alive. Position it to alllow them to get into caps safely. Not too far away so as to be of little use. You are their surrogate father. Look after them. Keep them safe. Its possible to use smoke in defence but it has to be done VERY carefully so as not to block your line of fire or benefit the enemy.
5. Talk to your squad. (Press T to find out who they are, Press I to chat to just them). Encourage them, instruct them. Tell them where to expect arty, when you're popping smoke etc. Organise them so you can mount a strong attack.

TL .. you need to be talking to your team constantly. Letting us know when and where arty will drop. Which area to attack and when NOT to attack.
You need to call in recon at the appropriate time, instructing your SL's to check their maps and provide new updated marks if required. You HAVE TO STAY next to the radio while the recon plane is up other wise enemies are not shown on th emap.
If you need to support an attack in a certain way then tell you SL's where you want their marks. Keep a constant eye on the chat and relay any important infor to the team (thats why you need a microphone).

Anti Tankers .. clue is in the name. You keep the team safe from tanks. If you don't do your job and instead decide to go sniping, your team will get slaughtered. DESTROY TANKS.

Engineers ..  you destroy tanks and tank barricades. When attacking you make a path for YOUR tank with the satchel. Blow fortifications to cripple defenders or alow ingress. When defending you destroy enemy tanks but your're also tasked with defending baricades etc. from enemy engineers.  It's your job to STOP them from being blown up.

Assault .. as it says .. when attacking your are the main thrust of the attack.

Auto Riflemen .. you are essentially an assault with greater range.

Riflemen .. You provide cover for the assault squads .. forcing the enemy to hide.  You then follow the assault into the cap and help consolidate. You then hold and defend the cap while the assaulters move onto the next cap, again providing them with cover and preparing to move on again once the assaulters have nearly secured the cap.
You can also resupply MG's. Walk, run or crawl up to them and press USE. This is an essential job since if an MG has to run back for ammo they're both at isk and leaving you without vital support.

Always use transports when provided. They allow you to follow up an attack much faster and to concentrate forces where needed. Therefor, never drive off in a transport on your own. Always wait until its mostly full.

Enemy recon planes can be shot down. Russian is a bi-plane, German mono. It loses them team points and recon info.

Team Kills, TK's, happen. they just do. If you TK, say sorry. If you're TK'd and the person says sorry, type np  (no problem), the TK will be forgiven, the person won't be kicked and your team will get a point .. because you were nice. Always forgive, np, TK's by arty .. it's usually your fault.

I could waffle for hours but I'll leave it at that.  It's a fantastic game once you get into it and understand how to play it to it's best.

reviewText:
Forgot to write to review for this game!

A game that has a bit a hard learning curve since there are a fair few keys to use, maps that are big and need to know where the objectives are and simply get familiar with them, but once you get the basics it start to become really fun and there is always something to learn as well as the game has a lot of depth.

Finally the ranking system is great to progress but still has a nice shape to let skilled players stand out in the battlefield.

One the finest wargames i have played for a while.

5/5 rating
