reviewText:
--------The Following Narrative Actually Happen in Red Orchestra 2---------

--------------------Bridges of Druzhina - 1942--------------
Russians...Russians are everywhere. They took objective A, B, and C so quickly that our fellow soliders began to panic. My Honor Rank is 73 and a squad leader for Squad Two. I ordered my men to fall back to Objective G, the outskirts of Druzhina, and command them to fortify the position. Squad One fought valiantly against the Russians on Objective D, but most of them were wiped out. The dense forest that cover Objective D and E favor the Russians than our German forces. The Bolsheviks were clever to use smoke grenades to advance their position while our men fired wildly into the thick, white smoke. What are they shooting at? Who knows.

As Objective E was spammed with Russians, the commander order the squad leaders, including me, to send in artillery coordinates. Unfortunately, there were too many artillery requests sent to the commander. The first coordinate is at the Russians on Objective E, the second coordinate is pointed directly at the Russian T-34, and the third coordinate was sent in close to Objective G. I was the one who sent in the third coordinate. I debated with my commander that the third coordinate is the best because the Russians would most likely be sending 2/3 of their forces to take G. The commander didn't listen and called the artillery at the first coordinate. As the artillery roars the sky and slams into the ground, the Russians were clever to run away from Objective E. Some of them died while the rest who were at Objective E rush to Objective G in a frontal assault. The machine gunner in my squad, whose Honor Rank is 58, fired his MG-34 in a control burst, but was killed by a sniper from 148 meters. I watch the machine gunner got shot and his body slump into the fragile, wooden floor. I was traumatized by this and order my men to not be exposed by the window. The rest of my squad consist of newer members, ranging the Honor Rank from 12 - 36 didn't listen to my command. The second squad member (Honor Rank - 26) was killed by the same sniper.

Two squad members killed and the Russians are swarming in front of the sandbags near Objective G...and I have to make a choice. I ordered my squad to suppress fire at the Russians while waiting for additional reinforcements to come and defend Objective G. Unfortunately, the Bolsheviks pulled a hard, right flank at Objective F, wiping out Squad Three in under 20 seconds. Even though my squad was able to pluck a few kills around Objective G, the Russians purposely made this frontal assault as a distraction so that their comrades can take Objective F. Knowing that Objective G would be overrun from the right side, I ordered my lower ranking members to retreat back to the apartments in Objective I. Strangely, there were signs of courage and fury in my men's eyes. One of the squad members (Honor Rank - 21, Anti-Tank class) demanded me to let him risk his own life as the T-34 rushes to the main road that leads to Druzhina. I refused in his request and ordered him to tactically withdraw, but he didn't listen. Before I was about to demand an order to him, he pulls out the Hafthohlladung anti-tank grenade and runs directly in front of the T-34. He starts to scream and was about to swing the grenade, but was mowed down in a hail of machine gun fire from the Russians. However, I heard an explosion and I took a slight peak in the window. The T-34's main gun was pointing in front of me and the last I said to my men is: Run! This is Red Orchestra 2.

------------------------------Review----------------------------
Red Orchestra 2 is the ultimate first-person tactical shooter that advocate very strong team coodination and communication, complex cover system, and each life (or ticket) is precious. When playing as the Russian, German, American, or Japanese, each solider fight just to survive. There will be instances in the game that discourage reckless assaults or exposure to the enemy. You will learn the game by experience and not repeating the same mistakes twice. There are weapons, class, and character rankings that encourages replay value. The best experience you will get in Red Orchestra 2 is playing on a full server. You will hear the best team coordination, the best varieties of newer and veteran players, and the greatest responsibility for your own life and theirs. Red Orchestra 2 does not shy away from the actuality of war as you will hear meeps, horrific groans, and the development of post-traumatic stress disorder. There is no I" in war; there is brother and comrade. Red Orchestra 2 is simply
date: the best tactical first-person shooter to ever develop."

reviewText:
Most realistic WW2 shooter on the market so far!

I simply love this game, and I do not like most fps. Finally a game that you cannot win by running/jumping around like mad, this only gets you killed within seconds. You have to be careful, snipe and cooperate with your teammates to be successful.

I love the graphics, the sound, the realism, the gameplay, even (a large part of) the community. Different weapons, (for a fps) long weapon reload times, limited ammo, severed body parts, even tanks to drive around - all I ever wanted!

reviewText:
One of my favourite ever shooters. I bought this game for about £3 - the price of a pint of beer. What a buy it was. It has provided me with hundreds of hours of gritty, immersive and extremely atmospheric gameplay. I love this game because it rewards noble gameplay: Patience, perseverance, precision, wit - compared to the homogenised, soft - edged generic excuses for FPSs that we are now spoon fed.
Yes, at first you will get shot from 150m countless times by someone you think must be invisible or hacking. Yes you will be frustrated at constantly being blown in to disgusting flesh lumps by artillery. Yes you will be annoyed that you can't be a sniper every match and are forced to use a boring bolt action rifle with iron sights.
However once you master the rifleman class the whole game starts to fall into place and you will realise that this is one of the best and most different" tactical experiences you have ever had.
9.5/10 I love this game and would absolutely recommend it if you are an experienced FPS player looking for more depth. However if you are a 14 year old with no patience

reviewText: After searching and searching, i have finally found a WWII game that is nearly perfect. In my opinion, it's my most favorite fps up to date. I rate it above Battlefield 4 and CoD 4 and put it next to BF:BC2. The only thing that they need to do now is come out with a Red Orchestra game for Vietnam with vehicles and everything and my life would be complete. The combat in this is spot on and much more dynamic and responsive than other FPS games I've played. Unlike BF4, you can actually play at 150 ping on a server and have no lag. I've had no problems with hit detection at all. On a scale of 1 to 10, I'd give this game a 9.7. The only thing it's missing is more vehicle accessible maps and airplane combat. That would make this a full WWII experience. I'll probably play this game more than I have played other FPS's. It's definitely worth picking up for 20 dollars. It's an amazing WWII game.

reviewText: The very first Communists were early Slavic tribes who owned so little they had to share everything. They were renowned warriors, whose battle tactics consisted of getting as drunk as mortally possible, then drink twice as much more and charge at the enemy wielding a hammer in one hand and a sickle in the other. Even in these early times they were called the Red Army for their red faces (esp. noses). A Communist Warrior was terrible to behold in battle, bashing, slicing, and breathing alcoholic fumes at his enemies. Mortally wounded, he would merely fall asleep at the field of battle, only to wake up the next morning with regenerated limbs, healed wounds and a severe headache.\n\n

reviewText:
Well Red Orchestra. I had so much fun with this game. community, gameplay, atmosphere, musics, soldier responds. They were all great. I played most FPS games on PC and consoles, and I can assure you this one is the best. Red Orchestra is the true first-person shooter that people deserve, not those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ casual FPS games which I'm not gonna name them and you already know what kind of games I'm talking about.
The stupid thing is I went and wasted my time on those ♥♥♥♥♥♥ nonsense FPS games. But I'll never make that mistake again, never.
The reason I recommend Red Orchestra is obvious, this is the most hardcore realistic FPS game that ever made, every class and role on this game has a reason, a commander can lead his/her team to success, a squad leader can make it possible to capture/defend an objective with smoke and squad spawn, a machine gunner can support his team with suppress fire, a sniper can bang enemy machine gunner, a assault soldier can go forward with his SMG and clear a room of riflemen. And the last and most important class which I spent 100 hours on is riflemen. They are the most effective soldiers in battlefield. They are the one who captures and defends from objectives.
Red Orhestra is the game that devs made with love, and we can see it in the game. I do 100% recommend this game to anyone is looking for a hardcore and realistic FPS game.
And my last word is, I wish more people get attracted to this game.

reviewText:
1)       It was 1943. My friend and I were holding the Russian front against the invading Nazi forces. They had us pinned down to our last territory. We held off the Germans and prepared a counter attack. Our counter attack was so strong we brought the war to the pacific front and we turned into Americans. TL;DR: Fought so hard we switched campaigns.

2)      The Germans were invading one of our cities, so I led my squad in the defense. There were two adjacent courtyards they were heavily open to enemy fire. I led my squad into a trench bordering the courtyards, and lost many in the process. My remaining friend and I go prone in the trenches dreading the inevitable German attack. Outside, about 20 yards from us, we heard a Panzer rolling across the ground. My remaining friend pulled out a satchel charge, and looked at me, and in that look we both knew what had to be done. I threw a smoke at the Panzer, and under the cover of the smoke my friend ran up to the tank and placed the charge, destroying the tank. However, before he could return to our position, he got ripped apart by enemy snipers. Shoutout to Karl XII for being a true war hero and ultimately winning the campaign for the Russian army. He will not be forgotten.




Best war game ever, hyper realistic, 1943/10

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2, or RO2, is an amazing game. It is, by far, my favourite shooter, because of its stunning grahpics, amazing visual effects, and great audio. It also stays true to the historical events of WW2, and is set around 1941, during Operation Barbarossa, with Soviet Soldiers clashing with the German invaders. The game also features vehical combat, which is a nice touch. There is a large ammount of weapons in the game, too, which are, for the most part, well-balanced. The majority of the maps in the game are quite vast and open, save for a few close-quarters combat maps. Red Orchestra 2 is all about tactics. The Team Leader is a key asset to every team, as he can call in artillery strikes and recon planes. Squad Leaders are important because they are a mobile spawn point for any player of the team. Riflemen and submachine gunners are the main fighting force for either side. Marksmen usually hide in bushes like the cykas they are and pick off enemies from a distance. And engineers can stop a tank in its tracks. But every class plays a key role in leading their team to victory.

In summary, Red Orchestra 2 is a phenomenal game with a few minor flaws that are made up for by the amazing gameplay, visuals, audio effects, and realism. It's a great game, and anyone who hasn't played it should give it a try.

PS, if you're a rookie player, be sure to have a keen eye, or you'll get shot by some unnatural force that you cannot see.

PS again, Soviets have the best rifle in the game and Germans have the best SMG.

reviewText:
THIS GAME IS:
10% luck
20% SKILL
15% CONCENTRATED POWER OF WILL
5% PLEASURE
50% PAIN

AND 100% REASON TO PURCHASE THE GAME.
*Shamelessly ripped from another review.
Anyways, this game is more than 20% skill, and certainly more than 20% luck. It is a simulator, not a game, in the same vein as ARMA II. Varying bullet velocities, ballistic drops, lack of a HUD must be taken into account at all times. Further, floating names over allies are rare, meaning that every shot could result in teamkill if the target itself isn't verified.
Each game is a battle of impulse and reflex as any FPS, but also of tactics and strategy, and most importantly of teamwork and situational awareness. Every corner is meticulously checked, every seemingly empty field is avoided or scoured, every street is treated as a funnel. Think fast, act fast, or die fast. It IS that simple.

reviewText:
The most entertaining multiplayer fps so far that has just the right amount of realism (this review is based on 'Realism' -mode of the game). Getting shot gets you killed (or disabled which is the same as killed in game terms) most of the time, depending on the weapon you get shot with: higher caliber weapons drop you with more certainty while pistols require more accuracy. Getting shot in the head or the heart (yes, the game lets you know where you were hit) kills anyone instantly. If you get lucky enough to survive a shot, you must spend a few seconds bandaging the wound or you will bleed out and die (yeah, not very realistic but very entertaining and exciting gamewise!). Also, sometimes you survive being shot for the few moments it takes you to bleed out from a serious wound that you cannot bandage: your screen starts to go black and you can no longer move, aim, reload or switch weapons. You can empty your current weapon in the general direction of the enemy sometimes getting lucky enough to hit them. Heroic effort, that! Nothing can save you from dying in this state, however.

The game simulates suppression by turning the screen gradually black and white while a loud thumping of your own heart can be heard. This indicates your soldier panicking in the midst of an artillery barrage (which causes the most suppression in the shortest amount of time), getting shot at (bullets hitting near you gradually make you panic) and finally fellow soldiers getting hit and dying near you. In game terms, you aim is lowered by the additional weapon sway and the screen effects make it harder (not impossible, just more difficult) to aim accurately.

The two sides (US and Imperial Japanese) are balanced in a way that - despite their numerous differences - offer a different experience in gameplay. Both sides have a set of limited roles ranging from the single team leader, several squad leaders, machine gunners, assault troops, snipers and an indefinite amount of riflemen up to the team size of 32 players. In addition the US get flamethrowers, and engineers carrying trench guns, while the Imperial Japanese have 'Knee-mortar' -soldiers.

Also the technology of the time is - to my knowledge - displayed accurately: the US soldiers are equipped with semi-automatic weapons (M1) most of the time while the Imperial japanese troops have to make do with their bolt action rifles (Type 38, Type 99). In some maps, like Guadalcanal, the US troops have bolt-action rifles (Springfield) as well since the M1-Garands had not yet been delivered to them (as is historically accurate). All in all, the US have more firepower at their disposal at any given time.

In return, the Imperial Japanese troops have bayonets from the beginning (which the US soldiers lack until upgraded) and they can banzai charge - resulting in higher suppression resistance - causing suppression in the enemy the more soldiers are joined in the charge - and the ability to withstand more hits than usual (headshots and shots through the heart kill instantly, as normally). The US troops suffer from suppression more easily than the Imperial Japanese troops. Japanese officers also get katanas, which are a cool way of disposing opponents.

In terms of weaponry, the Imperial Japanese soldiers can use their grenades as booby traps: 2 can be in place at the most by a single soldier at any given time. If you plant a third, the first one disappears. Yeah, again not very realistic but it balances the game. The booby traps can be seen plainly if placed on an open terrain with no vegetation and they can be detonated by shots, grenades or artillery fire. US soldiers walking over or very near one detonate it and most often die instantly while the Imperial Japanese soldiers can walk over them without triggering them. An US soldeir can, however shoot at a booby trap to detonate it in the face of any enemy soldiers (there's actually an achievement for this!).  The knee-mortar (as inaccurately named by US troops of the time; some poor ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s actually tried firing it from their knee, often  breaking their thighbone as a result) is basically a grenade launcher which must be setup prior firing. It can be deadly in accurate hands but is often a cause of accidental team kills among new players trying it, don't get discouraged if this happens and remember to apologize for team kills! A knee-mortar soldier gets 5 grenades to shoot at respawn, which can be replenished once at a single supply point like any other ammunition.

The flamethrower that the US  have, is a weapon feared by many Imperial Japanese players. A mere touch of its flames will kill you almost instantly and the flames fill a bunker quickly and completely leaving nothing alive inside. In contrast, the fuel runs out rather quickly, the range is limited,  and the US soldier carrying it is perhaps the most targeted soldier among enemy troops.

Both sides' team leaders must coordinate with their squad leaders to bring down artillery fire on, or near the enemy. This mostly acts as an area denial behind capture points so that the defending or attacking players are denied access to secure it. Soldiers finding themselves inside a barrage must get out of there quickly or get killed by the blasts: the game mechanic of artillery kills anyone inside the area over time. If you're very lucky, you can survive for a few seconds to run into safety.

The game has a honor system with ranks starting from 0 (new players) and ending in 100 - the highest rank available. The honor rank is account based and it is shown on a 'kill list' rotating on the upper right corner of the display (who killed who, how and where the shot it if a vulnerable spot) whenever you die or kill an opponent. You never know where the shot came from (unless you actually saw it your field of vision) as the camera locks instanly as you are killed so you can not look around to spot the enemy while dead.

The individual roles on a side (rifleman, machinegunner, squad leader etc.) get experience (team points) points based on performance in battle: staying near you squad leader or team leader grants you extra team points whenever you kill someone or help capture an objective (which in itself grants several points). Also extra points are awarded for killing someone FROM the object zone and even more if the TARGET was in the object zone as well. Normally, you get 2 ream points from a kill and -2 for a team kill.

A team kill can be forgiven by a player by saying 'np' in the public chat (the 'np' is not shown in actual chat) which removes the penalty from the player who caused it. It is generally polite to apologize for team kills and forgive them if the player causing it apologized. Sometimes you can guess with almost certainty that a team kill was an accident. Sometimes you just make the mistake of running into an area where someone just said they'd throw a grenade at or the team leader announced that the artillery barrage would strike in: in these cases you should own your mistake and 'np' immediately, especially in the case of team leader's artillery barrage which could result in numerous team kill penalties quickly. If you get enough team kills, whether accidental or not, you get kicked from the match and can't rejoin until the map changes.

Respawns in the game are periodic (a rotation of 16 seconds, I think) simulating waves of reinforcements arriving. The team leader has a limited ability (with a cooldown period) to instantly respawn all dead players. Both teams have a set number of tickets which dwindle as players keep dying. If the tickets reach zero, spawn protection is disabled and no more respawns can take place. Maps are also time limited and failure by the attacking team to capture an objective will eventually result in a lockdown period of 3 minutes during which they must capture the point or lose despite the time left on the map's time counter.

reviewText: RO2 (along with the Rising Storm expansion) is one of the most brutal first person shooters available.  This is one of the few shooters I have in my library that does not feel like an arcade experience.  Here are the following reasons I keep coming back to this game: suppressing fire and artillery cause your character to panic, affecting your aim and movement.  There are not countless weapons and upgrades to choose from; weapons are limited to squad availability, which forces teams to work together unlike other modern shooters.  You are easily killed, which forces you to move and attack carefully.  Finally, and most importantly, this game is hard...VERY hard.  It takes a while to get used to the play style and to properly explore the importance of the different squad roles.  This is one of those games where the first time you play it you will get killed very quickly and very often, not because there's some level 99 player with all of the weapons and upgrades unlocked kicking everyone's ♥♥♥, but because you haven't learned how to properly play the game.  This game is gritty, brutal, realistic, maddening, and a hell of a good time.

reviewText: Red Orchestra 2 is a World War 2 FPS which focuses on the eastern front. It mainly revolves around the bitter street fighting in the streets of Stalingrad and contrasts it with the openess of the surrounding steppes. RO2 scratches a multiplayer itch that no other competitive multiplayer game can quite get. It mixes small unit tactics and teamwork with high intensity and very authentic gunplay. The man who runs and guns in this is the man who gets shot first. Along with the authentic gameplay comes a steep learning curve. To those who tough it out RO2 is a multiplayer favorite and is an undeniably excellent game. Starting off with the core gameplay mechanics, RO2 attempts to; and arguably suceeds at; creating a tactical and authentic multiplayer experience that forces players to confer with their team in, at least a basic manner. The team with better communication generally comes out on top. Communication is especially crucial to the commander, who can call in off-map suppourts such as recon and artillery suppourt. These suppourts rely on coordiantes supplied by squad leaders and the platoon commander, thusly making teamwork a nessesity to win. Classes also play an improtant role. Given that M4 carbines are not the norm in World War 2, every weapon is more specialized. Riflemen are your typical grunts equipped with a bolt action rifle. These rifles are incredibly lethal and accurate making the rifleman key to providing suppourt to the other classes. Maachine gunners shut down kill zones and provide an alley for others to advance. Squad leaders assist the commander in providing coordinates and can use somke to conceal movement. Assaults get down and dirty in the ternches and go head on with the enemy with a sub machine guns. AT riflemen and Engineers provide a way to counter enemy armour at long and short range respectivley. These classes create a dynamic of cooperation between teammates, not one class dominates the battle. Gunplay is deliberate and lethal, One shot from any weapon has the potential to kill freind or foe. This gunplay makes short range combat flurried and confusing, while having long range engagments become a test of finesse and awareness. all of this gameplay is nicley wrapped in an atmospheric and compelling presentation. You crawl in dirty trenches to avoid rifle fire and artillery, knowing one well placed shot will end your life. The soundtrack potrays the mood of the battle, spurring you to action or spiraling into self loathing for losing to your opponent. Soldiers around you vocalize showing distain for their sub-human enemies, cowering in fear after coming under fire or writhing in pain while bleeding out after taking a round to the chest. The only real complaints regarding RO2 are it's steep learning curve, useless single player and some map glitches. The learning curve may turn some people off though once you get past it, RO2 is an experience that no other FPS can offer.

PROS:

- A lot of WW2 weapons and using them feels nice
- Pretty authentic WW2 experience with four sides to choose from (Japanese vs Americans, Russians vs Germans)
- No spray patterns :), but you must take the distance and recoil into account
- Class/role based and, as you gain XP, you improve your stats for weapons and classes
- The game is not limited to shooting only (rifleman, elite rifleman, assault, elite assault, marksman, anti-tank, machine-gunner), but you can also lead and command a squad (squad leader), operate a tank (tank commander, tank crewman), disable tank traps (engineer) or even command all the battlefield for your team (multiple tactical support options for a commander). Not all roles are available for all game types.

reviewText:
I've had this game for over a year now, but was never able to really play it until now (I had horrible framerate issues back then).

It's a realistic World War II FPS game.

-Weapons never stay centered on the screen
-You die in 1 to 2 hits (or you bleed out from non fatal injuries)
-Magazines are actually preserved (you don't regain unspent bullets from a changed mag; instead, the partially used mag is saved for later)
-There is no ammo counter. You check the number of bullets by feeling the weight of the magazine, or by pulling back the bolt of a rifle to count the bullets inside (done by holding the reload button). Even then, you won't know the exact number. It'll tell you if it's empty/near-empty/half-full/more than half/full.
-Suppression is a thing. If there's too much gunfire around you, your screen will turn black and white. Your character will start shaking, and you can't steady your aim down your iron sights.
-Bullet drop is a thing. When aiming down your sights, you can compensate for bullet drop by adjusting your view down the iron sights (done by scrolling up/down with the mouse scroll). The further a target, the more you'll have to lower your sights to get an accurate shot.
-There's a cover system. I don't use it much, but it's still there. You can also lean left/right.
-Roles are limited so as to prevent the Battlefield problem. Depending on the number of players, there can only be 1-2 snipers, 1-4 machinegunners, 1-2 elite assaults, 1-5 squad leaders, etc.
-There is a commander role. The commander is responsible for calling in aerial recon (to reveal enemy locations), force respawning (to support a large push against a capture point), and various types of artillery. Artillery coordinates must be requested from squad leaders, which further illustrates the team aspect of this game.

reviewText:
This game is hands down my favorite FPS game of all time. Granted customization isnt entirely great you have a few different weapons for each class and unlock the weapons for the other factions as you level each class (as well as stat improvement and attachments) but outside of that there is'nt anything. The combat and graphics make up for that by leaps and bounds.
The combat is very immersive and gets your blood pumping in intense situations. Storming a house/trench system, trying to defend and keep enemies out from your position, heart pumping close quarters combat not knowing who is around the corner or in the next room, the statisfaction you get when you pick some one off from over 100 meters away, how effective teamwork is and the impact it will make on how a round goes while trying to secure objectives or coordinate atry strikes.
Now the game can get very annoying and frustrating when your team is utter crap (like in every other game) since you can get locked down in the same spot and not be able to move or get any where without dying or your enemy just steam rolls through objectives. It is also a little difficult to tell the teams apart sometime but if you know the uniforms of the different nations its not bad. If you're new probably going to team kill often and really ♥♥♥♥ people off but its a learning curve.
The community is normally very helpful but also can be a little bit of eliteist sometimes. Its real easy to become a die hard fan of this game once you start getting decent and familarized with the game. So dont let some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s scare you off for TKing or not going for the right objective.

TL;DR

+great immersive combat/gameplay and graphics
+a lot of realism and historicly accurate weapons/battles
+huge battles and maps as well as small ones
+chain of command from commanders to squad leaders with differing perks

-very frustrating at first vs vet players
-possible elitists getting angry at you for being new
-low customization

reviewText:
Ok, So here is the review for Red Orchestra 2 with free Rising sun. I know the whole world has been eagerly waiting my next review. Don't worry you can stop holding your breath now it's here!

The graphics are alot better than they appear in the trailer let it be noted. Although it automatically sets them to lowest setting for graphics so to first timers It will look like a rubbish graphical experience. But if you change them in options it is perfect. I can run on second highest out of about 8 options of graphics settings and still have some of the highest ping I have ever seen (My PC is not the best for gaming, I will say that much ;)

Red Orchestra 2 (including Rising Storm) Is probably the most realistic combat simulator since Arma 2, And 5 times the fun.
For the first 5 hours you will find it damn near impossible to do anything right, Unless you are an MLG pro like me (add me on club penguin at [BlazeItMichael]_Xxx_B*tchesOnMyD*ck_Xxxv). Although it is definitley worth sticking with, as after the nooby period you will become Adept (Much Like Skyrim) And be able to run, duck, survive and pull off some pretty amazing if not entertaining as hell kills. Especially as a Japanese banzia charger. To clarify there are vehicles (Not as many as Heroes and Generals but still enough.) There aren't ships or planes as I suspect that would almost ruin the game. You have enough weapons to start with and all of them are useful for different playstyles. Going rambo with a flamethrower was my initial favourite.... Until I realised my whole team was Laughing at me :(
The game no matter what PC you have runs smoother than a very smooth and shiny rock (I didnt want to talk about Baby's bottoms because the NSA could be listening!) and the lowest I have seen my Ping being 80 no matter what server I'm on. Aswell the servers are up 24/7 and there is a constant dedicated fanbase of players online and with a perfect 32 a side on most servers there is no shortage of people to play with. There are also mod/community map and weapon and vehicle and texture supports including a workshop page.

I haven't had the game long. But I am now enjoying it and find it hard to put it down for five minutes. The time it took to write this review was torture enough without being able to snipe some soviet pigs!

There are 4 factions available Russia vs Germany and Japan vs US although more may be added through mods/updates.
And when you become a pro you will have the best time ever pulling off headshots from 300 meters with a rusty 70 year old soviet revolver.

Wow steam... The fact that you even dare to ask me wether I want to recommend this game or not is shocking....

P.S Has all the gore and laughs of Chivalry (Yes including a bit of teamkilling.) But runs ten times smoother and don't have to put up with as many hackers.

reviewText:
Personally i find Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 as the sweet spot between simulation/realism and action game.

I cant think of any other WWII game that came recently to replace RO2, it is the best WWII FPS out there and its a great game in its own category. Gameplay is very brutal for new comers, it has realistic gameplay and RO2 also has bullet drop which is a very nice feature!

RO2 is a huge game and it has a very hard learning curve, thats why many people buy it on sale then abandon when they die zillion of times without shooting down a couple of enemies...

In RO2 you see people crawl, sneak, hide, run, cry, taunt, swear, and explode just in front of your eyes.

All the chaos, artillaries and explosions makes you feel like youre really in the battlefield, not to mention the fear of facing a tank especially when the turret turns to your direction, I just ♥♥♥♥ my pants when that happens and pray the gunner didnt notice me!

Yeah I love RO2 because its a badass game. Recommended to people who love WWII Shooters and realistic hard game.

reviewText:
By far the best WW2 FPS out there. If you are completely new to the franchise it might bring some serious dying and teamkilling with it - HOWEVER - the atmosphere and the depths is just genius.
Different team roles and weaponry, giant maps and an awesome feel for the gruesome nature of war are just a few things to list.

Everybody who is sick of all the current gen FPS games should get this game, just because this is actually how a FPS is supposed to be.

reviewText:
A major improvement over Red Orchestra 1.
However after release it still has a couple of issues and bugs which the developers are trying to iron out.
It's a worthy successor to the first game, having realistic combat mechanics which prooved to be very enjoyable and authentic, while the atmosphere created by the music and phoenomenal sound is a very immersive and somewhat dramatic experience considering the setting.

I recommend getting it as soon as you can!

reviewText:
UNBELIEVABLE.

Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad is the sequel/expansion spinnoff to the original Red Orchestra.
The game is a World War 2 First Person Shooter designed to be multiplayer only, with a singleplayer campaign" against bots.
If this sounds boring
date:
it's only because this has been done SOOOO many times before.
So what makes this game stand out from the masses?
2 main things:
1) The painstakingly historical accuracy
2) FUN

Red Orchestra
hoursPlayed: has always been reccognised by those who know about it for it's historicaly accurate portrayal of World War 2. Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm continues this tradition to the (somewhat) extreame.\nThis is no Call of Duty

reviewText:
This game has given me the most harrowing experience in my whole career.
I was running through a set of factory doors and was faced with a Russian who I shot in the stomach.
He hadn't died.
He shuffled around gun in one hand, the other clutching his stomach. He was screaming Mama... Mama...".
After what seemed like an eternity he collapsed and died.
What had I done?

I screamed through my mic

reviewText: The best WWII shooter on the market, which is able to find a sweet balance between military simulations and arcade shooters. From the frozen battlefields of the eastern Front to the tropical vistas of the Pacific, RS/RO creates an immersive environment where every step and every shot are important. With a serious emphasis on teamwork, this shooter requires people to think before they act. This is no lone wolf" type game. You may start feeling like a child who's lost its mother
recommended: you may get to be an efficient killing machine. The only downside in this game must be the painful grinding for weapons. Though they are not dramatic COD like unlocks
hoursPlayed: they are quite difficult to get. The satisfying feeling of landing a head shot with a bolt action rifle on  a moving target 90 meters away will fuel many into losing themselves for hours in this game.\n"

reviewText: If you like Skyrim then this is the game for you. Red Orchestra 2 is the best JRPG I have ever played. It has many aspects of Western RPG's like The Elder Scrolls. For instance, WASD are the keys that you use to move around, just like in Skyrim. Although this game is based in a fictional world, it feels very real almost like this game was based on a true story. This is the perfect game for anyone that was a fan of Katamari. The gameplay is very similar in some ways. This is basically the video game version of the movie Casablanca which is why it is so good. My only complaint about this game is the graphics. The visuals look too good and I always get 60 frames which is too much for me. I prefer a buttery smooth 17-30 frames a second and at HD resolutions of 792p but no higher than that. 1080p is useless as the human eye can distinguish anything above 792p. Anyway, Red Orchestra 2 is the best MOBA on the market and I highly recommend it to anyone that liked Sleeping Dogs.

reviewText:
The best shooter known to man

This game is unforgiving, brutal, complicated and gives you no ♥♥♥♥ing quarter at all. However its also intense af and the lads from Tripwire put a lot of detail into everything. You drop dead the second an enemy looks at you. The guns feel great and anything that fires more than 1 bullet per minute is very hard to control. The command and class system is great. With the commander really being important and not just a cheap excuse to harvest kills with artillery strikes. Maps are well designed although sadly only a small percentage is actually played. Sound design is exceptional too everyone screams 24/7 either because your ♥♥♥ got torched by a flamer or youre giving orders. The community is great. If you thought  youve seen everything fire this game up and enjoy the voicechat. Its either a) 20 people talking about how uncle Adolf could have won the war or b) someone playing the national anthem of the Soviet Union performerd by the choir of the Red Army and 20 people singing along. With option 2 only taking place if youre currently defending the soil of RODINA from the grasp of some fashist svoloch.

A very underrated game really. Pick it up.

reviewText: Guys, this game is just amazig and awesome! U play either a german or a russian soldier in WW2. There are 3 gamemodes: 1st territory where the attackin team has to capture all of the enemys capzones; 2nd countdown where u have to capture more capzones during a given time then the enemy or 3rd firefight where you have to kill as many enemys as possible.\nIf u are a fan of CoD or CS u probable wont like the game cuz its a bit slower and the grafic isnt so amazing as in other games. The realy good thing of the game is the atmosphere: the soldiers speak in their mothertongue, scream for help if their under fire or comment the battle. The second in my eyes good thing is the realism. here ur very often dead after one shot and if not ur health doesnt regenerate instead u have to dress ur wound before u bleed to death. the weapons are realistic too: the recoil is bigger as in other games and u have to aim carefully. hipfire should be only used when ur skilled enaugh. U also can upgrad weapons and soldierclasses (like rifleman or engineer) to get awards like bayonet for some weapons or more or bigger mags. there is a level system too wich goes from 10 to 99. After reaching 80 u can play the classes u skilled enaugh as a hero wich brings a lot of advantages (like resisting barrages longer (ur sight becomes grey if ure under barrages for longer then a few moments)). the maps are mostly very big but there are some small ones too if u like that more. if u should have played liked RO1 too u should love this game too (but I heard that a few RO1 fans dont like that game). its more dynamic and much faster. the last thing i want to tell u guys is that there is the addon Rising Storm wich plays in the Pacific theatre (USA against Japan) and brings new weapons and new features (Flamethrower/Banzaicharge) to the game. Another addon (In Country:Vietnam") will be released in 2014. the only thing i dont like at the game are the bots. they re cannon fodder for disttances above 50 m (and waste reinforcements like this)
date: quickscope u witch the second shot on under 50 m and are very dangerous in melee o.O\nAll in all it just a great game and if u just have a bit of money ull have allot of multiplayer fun witch a lot of adrenalinkicks :D If u have any questions towards the game just messge me :D\nhope u buy it all and cya in the game :D"

reviewText:
Are you into amazing realistic World War 2 shooters ? Well this is the game for you. This game is defifnitely worth every penny, with amazing realism, gunplay, tactics, and community this is by far the best World War 2 game I have played since ArmA 2: I44.                             I reccomend the gamemodes: Realism and Campaign to be played together for the best experience of this game.
Amazing Graphics, gunplay is smooth and realistic (guns also look top notch), characters are well textured.

Set in the front line of Stalingrad this game opens a whole new world to realism players having the bold action of battlefield and the tactical realism of ArmA its a must buy game, very enjoyable with friends but also brilliant without. Most servers are good and you should probably add the best to your favourites, in the best servers players communicate and squad/team leaders work well together.


Graphics: 8/10
Realism: 9.5/10
Gunplay: 10/10
Emmersion: 10/10
Overall Game: 10/10

reviewText: As I cower behind my cover while me and my squad are heavily suppressed I see my squad leader turn to us and then stand out of cover to try to get a shot at the enemy only for him to take a bullet in the gut. The enemy didn't even give him the curtosey of finishing him off...they let him just bleed there holding his stomach as he screamed I'll be okay don't worry about me just move!" and then he faded. 14. win
15. 10/10 i will play again with more level

I do suggest playing with a server that is full with bots , there you can train, upgrade ,even get more level

reviewText:
you will come home from the war a jaded veteran. your dreams are dead and your wife will try, but the passion is gone forever. the more you're home the more you want back out there. you'll start drinking, to muffle the sounds of dying comrades and blazing foes alike, one night you'll have a little too much and slap your wife around when she tries to pass off a tv-dinner as her own creation. she'll cry and you'll promise her it'll never happen again, but as you go through the motions day by day, you feel more and more empty inside.

until finally you'll find salvation is the barrel of a gun pressed against the roof of your mouth, your brain splatter the canvas with which you paint your way to valhalla, the cheers of comrades in arms once more battering against your eardrums.

welcome home, warrior

reviewText:
This game is very well done. I would recommend. I generally play TE-Realism (territory-realism) so cannot speak for much else, so I will focus on what I know.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~Disclaimer-I wrote this the day the Troop Transport and etc. patch came out so I cannot talk for the new game mode nor have I encountered how the transports affected the gameplay (though I doubt this will change my review at all).~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Now onwards:

First off, I would not recomend this game for a drop-in drop-out team-deathmatch style play. The real beauty in this game lies in it's tactical layout that is fully fleshed in the territory game mode, which has a chain of command from Lt. to Sgt. to Riflemen(or whatever you are playing as) with players taking each role as able. Platoon to squad to individual in other words.

In order to succeed in this game, teamwork is one-hundred percent essential. If you want to be an mg, you are going to need someone to give you ammo when you run dry and to protect your six. If you want to be a sniper, you have to pay attention to what your team is calling out, and to prioritize the correct targets (do you hit the enemy sniper, team leader, or engineer?).

Realism mode is exactly how it sounds. bullet pen. and deviation happens, getting shot in the leg slows you down, and if you don't patch your wounds you will bleed out and die (if you aren't killed outright already). AT rifles can't penetrate the SLOPED front armor, and the ppsh is a *ahem* on the recoil aspect.

Only three complaints: sometimes people join a match only to mess with others (via chat, TKs, etc.) This is not that big a problem, and if such a person arrives it is an easy procss to kick said individual. Secondly, the roles can be taken very quickly and sometimes matches are just bad (usually for the russians because the russians seem to never have good teamwork). With some patience and perseverence this can be over-come however. Finally, and my main complaint, people often drop out of matches when they are over. While this is not a bad thing per se, usually if a team gets absolutely wiped during a match almost invariably 50% of the team throws out some form of pessimistic this team sucks/what noobs/I hate my team" and quits the server. Invariably this only furthers the disparity in the teams
date: as one side slowly accrues vets who are have a lot of experience that day on the server working together while the other is constantly rotating new people who have base teamwork.\n\nThese problems are entirely player-based and as such are no fault on the game itself
recommended: and I 100% recomend this to whoever reads this.\n\nIt CAN be said that this game is extremely hard
hoursPlayed: both in the beginning and later on. I was there
voteText: dying sixty times a match
helpfulPercent: never getting a kill
votesHelpful: etc. At level 60+ now I can honestly say
votesTotal: it is just experience. Like in a real war the greenies do poorly at first
votesFunny: so it is here. Just keep trying
commentsCount: find good people to play with
column16: and learn from the vets and you should do fine. It IS a hard game
column17: and it IS worth the trials you might face every once in a while.\n\nEDIT: Troop Transports and whatnot did not affect the game in any negative way at all. While sometimes people cheese them and block doors to objectives
column18: or use the mg as a mounted gun this only adds more to the realism of the game: people build barricades to defend themselves
column19: and more mgs seems like a great idea. Plus
column20: you can throw grenades over the transports. Both teams get transports if transports are on a map. While I do believe the Soviet is faster
column21: the germans have a better gun and can carry more (i believe). All in all
column22: still a most excellent game."

reviewText:
A World War 2 era combat simulator, RO2 entails eastern front battles between Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union. Highly realistic gameplay mechanics leave no room for silliness on the battlefield! While the single played is a time waster, multiplayer is where the heart of the game is.

Rising Storm is a reskinned addon which includes new maps and weapons based on the pacific battles between Imperial Japan and (Imperial) US. Each RO2 buyer can play on RS maps but can only play as a rifleman.

It is worthy to mention that this game has been updated countless times with new weapons and maps - all of which were free.

The price of this game alone is enough to justify a purchase.

reviewText:
This is probably the best multiplayer shooter up to date.

The game is semi-realistic, which means it tries to be both realistic and fast at the same time. A single bullet means death if it hits head, heart or lungs (in case of lungs it's not an immediate death though as you can still shoot while dying), but a bullet to less vital parts of a body will only cause a wound. A bullet shot into enemy's weapon will effectively disarm him. Granades are very deadly as they should be, which is important to mention, because in many games their effectiveness is downplayed. Wounded legs will slow you down, wounded arms will negatively affect your accuracy.

The game is very fast as there are tickets" that let players respawn until they run out
date: hence there usually isn't too much turtling and the game heavily discourages such tactics anyway due to maps
recommended: use of artillery and so on. Many maps allow multiple tactics as they usually allow two (sometimes even more) points to attack for a team
hoursPlayed: hence the defenders need to spread out
voteText: and attackers can decide where to focus on pushing the enemy forces.\n\nThe game provides multiple classes to choose from
helpfulPercent: but the better and more important ones are limited
votesHelpful: and interestingly not every player is equal - some get better weapons
votesTotal: some get worse
votesFunny: but also some are leaders
commentsCount: while others are cannon fodder. But it is fun regardless of what class you are playing (although you might have your favourite one). The game isn't about being the best in the team
column16: it's about helping the team. It is very encouraged by the game's mechanics and affects the game in a very significant way
column17: hence why the game doesn't play like another random multiplayer shooter #241221. It's unique in its own way. I definitely recommend it to everyone who enjoy multiplayer action games
column18: regardless if they prefer realism or arcade
column19: as this game is somewhere in-between (albeit inclines more towards realism than arcade). The only negative things I can say about this game is that albeit its realism
column20: bullets do not penetrate objects (which is a serious flaw)
column21: and the fact that unlike previous games by Tripwire RO2 doesn't support anything besides Windows operating system."
column22: April 6
column23: true

reviewText:
Why I love this game? Because in order to use a weapon effectively you need to learn how a weapon acts. You need to learn how a weapon reacts like the PPS or PPSH 41 before you start to  hate it because you hit nothing . You also have bots most of the time on the servers, if there are no players. The bots play smart. They storm, rush, defend or aren´t able to react because of artillery or suppression. The bots are excellently executed in their programming and you can have a very intense fight even with just those, a very own regulated fight! The battles in this game are always intense and require player actions. You smoke the front of an MG Nest so the enemy players or bots have their field of sight cut off, you then can storm the objectives, push the enemy back or control the battlefield by being the commander, suqad leader or just any regular class or call in artillery to cut off reinforcements. Players teamwork with each other as they are intrigued in getting the win is a often happening thing. This game has so much detailed work in it, so much precise teamwork and fighting like in no other game on the market. Red Orchestra 2 is a masterpiece of combat and battlefield simulation. The wonky, at first, yet easy to understand controls are FANTASIC. The gun combat being perfectly tuned. The balancing and the strategic elements are a mash up of skill and realism. Just 1 hour of combat equals 10 hrs of any other games wannabe strategic finesse. I might play 250 hrs Call of Duty, but it won´t come near 1 hr of Red Orchestra immersion. This game is a pinnacle and mastery of its genre. Get it! Play it! Feel the battlefield and the combat! It´s more than just video game programming! It´s fun no matter the circumstance even with AI, even with amateurs! I played and felt so into it that I wanted to truly get rid of the enemy! I wanted to win! I wanted to let the enemy feel the pain of defeat! I take my Thompson, SVT, C96, MKB, G41, PPSH 41, no matter what and storm the building, I take down 3 guys and continue! Every second being the last I think. Yet i survive! ADDICTION.

There was a time when the crickets were loud and the sun was hot, but without the rivers of blood. My homecountry was invaded, our push failed. The bolshevik danger coming close, the nazi propaganda all just lies. My name is Frank Eisenherz, I was born and raised in times when my fellow Germans were in bad mind and the country in ruins. They enlisted me without my approval, like most of my friends at that time. We had to, we also wanted victory for previous shame and defeat. Regain what was lost with strength and brutality. What fools we were singing under the iron cross for the swastika fascist scum. Several nightskies ago I clenched strong to my MKB42 prototype, a weapon ahead its time. Many red died by my hand. I wake up with the worst of nightmares, insomnia and a decayed mind. After defending bridges and storming apartements, fighting the russians frequently, I realized that we lost the war a long time ago. No matter the intensity of my fights, the realism of war hitting me or the horror of death screaming in front of you, you always come back to the battlefield. The names of the brave men that fought right beside you popping up inside your head. Foxholes getting creamed, soldiers losing limbs, screams of agony and tears so heavy they could crush a tiger I. If you want to survive this war, better take your gun and don´t be afraid to charge, don´t be afraid to be too patient. It will save your life.

Once you entered this world, you can´t return. 10/10

reviewText:
There are many World War 2 shooters that exist and seem to copy themselfs over and over again, thankfully Red Orchestra 2 and its sister, Rising Storm, do not suffer from this fate. Red Orchestra 2 and Rising Storm are unique games that include a single player that is great, but not at the same level as its multiplayer.

In multi-player You can play as several diffrent roles, a few being: Commander, Squad Leader, Rifleman, etc., and all of these roles play a unique part in building a strong team. There is 1 Commander per team and this person's job is to manage and try to set up strategies that his whole team can agree on and execute with together, fire artilery, and other such things. Squad Leaders can act as moible spawn points for squad members, give commander marks to fire artilery on, use smoke grenades, and other things. Rifleman are the most common role, as the majority of the server's players will be rifleman. You have a bolt action rifle (as Americans in Rising Storm, it is possible you get the M1-Grand instead) and your job is to take the objective points and be supportive and coopertive of what your other team members ask you to do.

With game servers that can cap at 64 players, massive maps that can take 10 minutes to run across, one of the best atmospheres ever to be designed, great balance with roles and teams, a great community that works together as a team, and with the toping of higher-end graphics, Red Orchestra 2 and Rising Storm can easily be one of my favorite games and easily my favorite FPS.

reviewText: This game can be pretty intimidating at first and you'll probably die a lot before you even see enemy soldiers. It's really based more on knowledge than raw skill. You don't need to have good twitch reflexes (though they can help) to be a good player. You need to know how the maps work, where your team needs you most, when to move, and how to not die. Generally one side attacks and one side defends. It is crucial to coordinate with your team, especially while attacking. There definitely seems to be a strong correlation between how many knowledgeable guys on your team are using microphones and how often your team wins. If somebody says Everybody needs to bonzai charge the cap zone NOW!" you'll be surprised how quickly 20 or so Japanese soldiers are screaming into the smoke straight into the cap. You don't need to use a mic yourself
date: but you'd be wise to listen at least some of the time to your teammates advice (don't worry about the crazy guy that is screaming nonsense at his computer).\n\nOverall it's a very fun game but has it's problems. Single player is pretty much non-existent if you care about that
recommended: the movement feels a little clunky and can be awkward when a player interacts with the level geometry. They unnecessarily split up the game into "action" and "realism" modes when it's obvious this game caters to the realism audience. It lacks some polish
hoursPlayed: but it's not a $60 huge budget game so that's to be expected. There could be more maps and more vehicles
voteText: especially the latter which have been neglected since the first RO.\n\nAll in all
helpfulPercent: a good game at a good price."

reviewText:
Tired of having to buy extra DLC just to feel like you are getting the full expeience? Or perhaps you are tired of the enemy soaking up bullets and never actually dying.

Either way this game overcomes such issues and goes beyond anyother FPS game I have seen before. The stunning attention to detail in the animations and models is a joy to see and the maps feel realistic. There is also a fear present in this game, something that most other games lack, a knowledge that you could be shot from out of nowhere or that you could have been flanked without seeing it.

On top of all of that the community is fantastic and there will always be people trying to commuincate in game.

So would I recommend this game?

Yes whole heartedly, it is always enjoyable.

I woke up to see this game in the steam store, I quickly downloaded it to see what the hype was all about, as soon as it was downloaded I was about to click the play button when all of a sudden I got a knock at the door, I was startled at first so I jumped up to check the peep hole, and whoever it was on the other side had their finger over it so I got suspicious an grabbed my gun, I yelled who's there!?" No reply so I asked once more... I got the same silence so after contemplating for the next several minutes I decided to open the door.

My initial reaction was to shoot....BANG...BANG...BANG... I stood in shock as I found out it was my american stepbrother.
I was in tears

reviewText: First of all you want to be playing this game for the multiplayer, the singleplayer while has some well voiced openings is buggy to all hell with the bots. The meat is in the multiplayer the game is really fun and pretty realistic although there are some problems with the game, the core is good. Veterans of the game devour new players like nothing, so if you dont want a horrible beginning experience or dont have the time to learn the game you are not going to enjoy this game. It takes alot of observing and learning of the maps to realize whats really happening. For the most part balance wise it is really balanced with a few guns being really good, alot better than rising storms balance. Its a great game if you really get into it, just prepare to get your butt kicked a lot, but hey defeat can be a learning experience.

reviewText:
Another FPS game.....  ....But this one is the most intense and thrilling one!

Red Orchestra 2 is giving players the opportunity to experience the close quarters combat and the most open battles of the Second World War.
This game includes a great engine which allows you to get some very nice gameplay.
RO2 has many maps, snowy fields to soviet building blocks. A great way to expand your experience is to buy Rising Storm with it. It features the Amercans and the Japanese forces who will fight eachother in Asia! This game is realism all the way! Flamethrowers, booby traps, banzai rushes. RO2 + Rising Storm is a good one to pick up.

So, do you want to expierence the WW2 in a unique way with great multiplayer? Go pick up this game! Still wondering if it's worth your money? Watch video's on Youtube or read more reviews on the internet to learn the game more.

reviewText: Ill start this review by saying that Ive played a great deal of WWII games in my time, including franchises such as Medal of Honor, Brothers in Arms, Call of Duty, Day of Defeat, and many other small companies many people probably haven't heard of. After all of this times spent on WWII gaming (as it is a historical interest of mine as well) I had lost a bit of my interest. Red Orchestra, however, reinvigorated my passions by delivering a realistic and unique shooter. Although the single player campaign is fun to play, most gamers will find the most fun in the multiplayer. The game blends class-based skills and teamwork on detailed maps that will bring you as close as you would want to be to the Eastern Front. Sometimes you will experience weapon jams, suppressing fire, fatigue, and non-lethal wounds that you cannot simply walk away from. For example, if you are hit in the leg while sprinting from cover, you will slow down or even stop, simulating something that most franchises cannot. I will end the review with some simple advice: If you are looking for another Call of Duty, don't look here. Play Red Orchestra for the realism and the unique fun that it offers.

reviewText:
Call Of Cuty is a game for children. This is a game for men. COD kids get out.

This is my favorite WW2 game by far. This a great and realistic game with a lot of depth.

Here is a quick overview:

You will play as a soldier of either the Red Army, the Wehrmacht, The U.S. Marines, or the Imperial Japanese Army. The game is set in two theaters of war, The Pacific (U.S. Vs Japs), and the Eastern front (Russians Vs Germans). In each army, there are different classes such as rifleman, assault, marksman, and so on. As you progress in the game, your weapons will level up and get attachments/upgrades, and look like they are in better condition. The class you are playing itself can be leveled up to give you more weapon/sidearm choices. Finally, you can level up your account with Honor". The higher that level is
date: the more battle hardened your soldier is and the more things overall you can choose from.\n\nI recommend you play the training missions
recommended: and I partially put that here so I wouldn't have to type anymore stuff...\n\nIn any case

reviewText: It would be fair to say the Red Orchestra player is a niche market, however the gritty and often grimm action of the first game is faithfully enhanced; both gameplay and graphics have been improved and although the unreal engine looks good enough it may be enough to deter the pretty boy gamer. This is a shame as this game offers one of the most authentic WW2 shooter experiences ever concieved! Both tense infantry battles and epic tank engagements feature heavilly in Red Orchestra 2, on the ground the horror of war is unleashed with good visuals, sounds and plausible environments. And in the tank the player feels claustrophobic, trapped and confined although possesing some serious firepower the tank crew must work as a team to be effective. All in all an ultra realistic take on WW2 from both the Soviet and Axis perspectives, a must for 3rd person shooter multiplayer nuts...

reviewText:
Best online FPS I've ever played, hands down. When you first start playing, the game overwhelms you with tactical information, but if you read the user guides, you'll pick up the finer points of the game quickly.

Teamwork is critical in winning a match, since each class provides a necessary role on the battlefield.
The commander role is almost a different game in itself, because without a good commander, battlefield support is nowhere to be found. A bad commander ensures teamkills and inevitable loss.

Lot of hardcore players on here, and it would be wise to have a mic. 10/10

reviewText: A perfect game for a tactical gamer. RO2 offers slow paced gameplay and rewards smart positioning, flanking manuvers, and above all teamwork in order to win the game. 90% of the time players will be using a slow firing bolt action rifle and firing at ranges anywhere from 0-200 meters. The action is unrelenting and the game has a gritty realism to it as the soldiers scream and bullets and grenades explode everywhere. RO2 is perfect for anyone searching for a change from COD, Battlefront, or ARMA.

reviewText:
I'm addicted to this game. I enjoy it alot and recommend to anybody who likes action and realism.

Reasons:
- no 3rd person, so no everpresent jackassing known in Arma 3
- HUD is hidden most of the time, improving the immersion much.
- difficult to play, but very rewarding both wits & skills
- TANKS that are quite realistic and enjoyable
- no better multiplayer game focused on infantry and combined operations at this moment. Sorry, BF3/BF4 is fun for boys.

Being addicted to RO2 doesn't mean I don't see its flaws. Quite many of them actually:
- lame interface programming
- lack of positional voice communications (ACRE!)
- no simulation of speed of sound
- Hollywood bullet whizzing instead of sonic cracks
- role voting has been removed
- poor network coding (in MP game!) - lots of presumably local events must be confirmed by server.
- no automatic detection of possible weapon support positions
- realism suffers from streamlining: people sprint unbelievably fast to increase tension; bullets fly faster than IRL to counterbalance it..
- leveling leads to absurdal situations; lvl 50 machine guns can be fired with almost no penalty from hip
- using meelee makes your character stop in place
- cannot throw grenades away
- cannot throw satchel charges away
- tanks are coded awfully to say the least
- only two types of tanks, no APCs, cannons

Overall: Good

reviewText:
One of THE best games ever. The combat is so much better than most other FPS games I have played. I have been craving a game that allows you to blind fire since I played Killswitch on the PS2 . And this game allows you do just that! you can throw grenades around corners without exposing yourself either. Machineguns overheat and if you continue to fire the barrel warps and you have no choice but to change it. Commanders can use binoculars to spot and call in Recon which flies over head and shows where the enemy is but only on the map and the commander has access to Mortars, Artillery and Rocket Barrage to wreck havok on the battlefield.


The suppression system is very well made  shoot some bullets at an enemy and his aim will be too shaken to aim back and then you can deliver the final blow. Now that is realism! The lack of vehicles for a game thats been out this long is the only thing I really hate about this game at this point. I wish they would make more, but I have heard that they are not making more as they are working on a Vietnam game can anyone confirm this as I really wanted to see a Tiger in this new Ro2.

The bullet drop works well but there are few maps where you can use anything more than 400m
I have only been able to use the Bullet Drop to effect on several maps. I can only really vouch for the Axis as I have only played for the Axis on the Eastern front and Allies for the Pacific Campaign. To the Pros and Cons

Pros
THIS IS A TEAM GAME
- Blind fire System that acutally works.
- If you don't use teamwork you will fail!
- Tank Battles are awesome.
- Leveling system is great.
- Mulitple game modes
- Working Bullet physics
- You can yell Most Dishonorabr in Rising stormand everyone will start yelling similar things and laugh with you USUALLY
- You can Nut shot people with bullets. (you can tell when you see a cracked acorn icon for a kill message)

Cons
-Japanese get a knee mortar that can get really annoying after you get killed multiple times.
-Finding servers with ping near you is a MUST if you are to get a kill as you must aim in front of someone to compensate for the high ping if you are to kill anything if you do join a high ping server.
-The grind gets really old after a while.
-2 types of tanks for each side in the Eastern Front side and a 1 transport. No vehicles in Rising Storm.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the top-tier finest FPS WW2 shooters to date. Honestly, haven't gotten into it all that much before hand, but when I actually settled down to play it, holy hell is it addicting. Graphics are superb. Love the detail, the sense of realism in every battle, historical or not. This really takes the cake for me. Communication between players is much MUCH better than I excpected. People actually know what they're saying and or doing. Makes team battles really fun when you're able to execute your objective with finesse. Rain Silves would be proud.

10/10 - People yelling orders at me and I succumb like the infantry grunt I am.
10/10 - Rain Silves is proud.

Go into this game completely unprepared like i did.

reviewText:
This game is one of my favorite games if not my favorite game of all time.

My experience with this game started way back in 2012 when my computer was all but a potato, that could barley handle CSGO on let alone a game like this. It caught my eye on the Steam Store when it was on sale. I have always had a facination with WWII and this game looked perfect. I could imagine myself as a Russian running into a room with my PPSH and unloading the entire clip into a whole squad of Germans. Or as a German Sniper laying on the edge of the map picking off unsuspecting Russians with my Kar98 (Scoped). But what peaked my intrests the most was the Pacific Theater never before had I seen a game where the devs acually were devoted to making a game as realistic as it is and before the EA,Orgin fanboys say it, yes it is more realistic that Battlefield. All the weapons are pieces of their time, and most of the attachments are legit too, and the classes the same (*sigh* exept the flamer). The battles are amazing, teamwork is a must and a good team leader can change the tides of any battle, and if all of your team is cooperating
you will completely wipe the other team, although battles can last upwards of 30 minutes each (which is my biggest complaint) they are almost always satisfing and when you lose you can almost always say. Yeah that was my teams and my team only's fault."

Final Analysys

Gameplay: 9/10

Multiplayer: 8/10

Graphics: 8/10

Audio: 7/10

Controls: 7/10

Final Score:

8 1/2 / 10"

reviewText:
This game is fantastic. You get a vague feeling of really being on the eastern front / pacific theater. You will need both your eyes and ears when playing this game. What is even better is that the game is like a living museum in some way. Weapons sound different, depending on their kind and even their distance. After a bunch of games, you might be able to hear if there are enemies or friendlies shooting near you. Then there are the amazingly detailed tanks and buildings. Some maps can look familiar if you've seen some Stalingrad documentaries.

There is a steep difficulty curve. You can't just go Rambo on everyone. Knowing your weapon and the aprox. magazine size is also vital for your survival. Give it a try at a free weekend before buying.

MP40 double magazine was here; PPSH can go have intercourse with itself

reviewText: This game is a team based, tactical shooter in military simluation style. With the two main game diffilculties being Action and Realism. Realism is the preferred option, and most servers will use this. The game is unforgiving and has a steep learning curve. With one shot deaths, and a suppression system. The game does not involve much in terms of ballistics physics, but it does not remove much from the gameplay. If your looking for a great realistic WW2 shooter, then this is your ticket, if your looking for a WW2 counter strike, you should look somewhere else!

reviewText: The first thing that I'm going to say in this review is that you will die in this game. A LOT. However, thats some of the fun as you learn to master covering from fire and tactics. I've got to say, after playing this game thus far, no other FPS I've ever played other than those of the ARMA franchise has come even close in terms of scale, realism, and strict reliance of teamwork. Yes, it might be a much slower paced shooter than your generic run and gun game, but the slower pace only helps to reinforce the realism of how war isn't all about just shooting the bad guys, but about tactics and teamwork. Without strong teamwork, you will almost always lose. The guns are all balanced and realistic with an interesting distance adjuster, and the way that the class system works, you always end up with a balanced team instead of a team filled with only snipers and machine gunners. The gunplay is fantastic, and the fact that there is a cover system, something sorely lacking in most modern military FPS's, was just icing on the cake for me. If you are even remotely interested in a historic military game or one based more on tactics than trigger fingers, then this is the game for you.

reviewText: I see a enemy Russkie infront of me. He slowly reloads his gun  un-aware of my presence so I walk towards him with a smile on my face and my Iron sight aimed right between his eyes. Our eyes connect and I see horror and fear as his eyes widen. He suddenly stops reloading his gun knowing his doom is here. *Click* My stomach drops as I notice my gun was empty this whole time so my eyes begin to tear up as I begin to reach down into my pouch for another clip, doing so my hands are shaking and the only thing I can focus on right now is reloading my gun. The next thing I know is our Situation has switched. Now it is me the scared and frightened person and him the Cocky/proud person with a helpless enemy in his sights. My eyes closed, I hear a loud bang and suddenly .... Nothing.  20/10 - Would get cocky and not check my ammo from time to time.

reviewText:
Why i Love Rising Storm!



This is my favourite game of all time, Before i found rising storm i was a big strategy gamer mainly total war. Shogun 2 got me interested in the Japanese and i started having a look at its history. By early 2014 i was all the way into the Imperial Japan era and i wanted to play a game based around then. Now there really arent many games set in the pacific which is a shame since its such a interesting era and theatre of war but i managed to stumble across a game called Red Orchestra 2/Rising Storm. Now when i played this i was blown away....Not only did it not spam you with DLC it gave me both expansions for free! it was realisitic! proper bullet times and factors for each gun! each gun made in perfect detail with all its flaws and advantages as in real life, never has firing a type 38 arisaka or a kar98k been so entertaining in a game for me. even after playing all the maps hundreds of times it never gets old because the community is so fun.

The team work is like no other. this isnt battlefield where everyone runs off doing their own thing people work together in this to achieve victory its simply amazing!. The native voice acting for the Germans Russians (American voices are pretty bad though) and Japanese is simply outstanding the japanese even have a Kansai dialect for added detail, its absolutely insane the gun play is awesome the push and shove of battle feels real. even when you see a flash 200m away and half a second later your dead does it not fail to impress. the realisim is done perfectly in time with the fun.

Most of the few Pacific War games are rather historically innacurate without mods. But rising storm Nails everything prefectly (except for the SNLF having later date uniforms when they should have green but a mutator fixed this as well as being put on some servers) This Game to me is more immersive then a movie like saving private ryan its, i literally get excited to just jump on and play every time. I have even put 100 hours into the Steam Offline mode wih bots it never fails to entertain me.

So people coming here looking for a reason to buy i guarantee you Rising Storm will not disapoint you if you want something realisitic and historically accurate. and for the fun its just so worth it.

MUTATORS/MODS I RECCOMEND TO IMPROVE EXPERIANCE.
Beta SNLF: This changes the Khaki SNLF skins to the correct for timeframe Green Naval Uniforms. this is literally the only gripe i have in the realisim department so i reccomend this if you want to see the Japanese Marines in the correct garb (the previous is also correct but like late 1945 not 1943)
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=626136687
for server operaters use this version: or if you are a user you can request your server admin puts this on the server
http://www.moddb.com/mods/beta-snlf/downloads/beta-snlf-v104-21616-client (alternate offline play version)

http://www.moddb.com/mods/beta-snlf/downloads/beta-snlf-v104-21616-server

(server version for server operators)

PACIFIC ARMOUR: Tanks dont appear in RS unless you have this mod. mainly for offline play but there is a server operator option. ONLY GET FROM MODDB STEAM WORKSHOP VERSION NO LONGER SUPPORTED

http://www.moddb.com/mods/pacific-armor/downloads/pacific-armor-v101
http://www.moddb.com/mods/pacific-armor/downloads/pacific-armor-v101b

reviewText:
I am a casual gamer and introduced to the franchise after RO2.

This game started as a terrible game. Performance issues, balancing issues and all sorts of problems you can get from rushed launch. Tropwire took there sweet time to fix most of the lingering issues, but now I am saying with full confidence that this is one of the better FPS on PC. The whole experince is unique and shooting feels way more different then the likes of COD or BFs.

Though community is small, but all of them are dedicated which results in faboulus gaming sessions. It has a slight learning curve and game dosent explain well the fundamentals. You need to learn it through Youtube are spending few hours in the game messing around. Basically it plays more like the RUSH mode from Battlefield series.

SP and COOP portion of the game is as good as non existent. Game is regularly updated with new maps. Even a new DLC was given for free with slight restrictions. All in all I am a highly satisfied with the efforts of DEVS to improve the game.

If you like FPS games with a slight learning curve and teamplay then this game is ideal for you.

reviewText: This Game is a Masterpiece. I never felt so, so Sad about Soldiers being killed by either Gunshot Wounds or Explosions. Every corner you turn decides your Fate. Every Descision you make determines the Fate of you and your Teammates. I highly recommend this Game. 10/10
