reviewText:
This is pretty much a multiplayer only game, reviewing it as such is crucial.  If you're looking for a single player experience, look elsewhere.  That being said, this game is amazing.  RO2 is a modern looking, realistic WW2 FPS.  Though it started out with more than a few bugs, it has been updated and polished quite nicely over the years.  Before I get into details, I'll also include that you will get to experience both the Eastern front as well as the island battles of the Pacific Theatre, easily one of the most unique features about this game.

Gameplay is quite fluid.  Moving around the map, crouching, sprinting, all feel quite good and realistic.  Sounds, weapons, chatter, maps, and skins all create an immersive atmosphere.  The horrors of war will be on full display the minute you step into a populated server and you're going to love every second of it.

Though the learning curve of RO2 is moderate to high for most, which I personally love, this is ultimately a game of realism.    You will most certainly die from one well placed shot, but you can also do alot of damage with one placed shot yourself.  Though, one man can do quite a bit of damage to the enemy if he knows what he's doing, this game stresses teamwork tactics and sticking close to your squad mates.  Getting into cap zones, and picking guys off from there is the name of the game.  Working with your teammates and coordination is key.  You won't find much in regards to Rambo'ing around the map as it simply won't work unless your an experienced veteran.

Easily one of the more realistic WW2 shooters out currently.  I've played this game since launch, and over the last few years, the game has made great strides towards being very, very good.  With the most recent update, which included the release of the MG42, battles on the Eastern front feel about ten times more intense.  Worth every penny, would buy again.

reviewText:
I play this game on lowest graphics settings, on a laptop that is just on minimum spec for the game. It is still an immersive, exhilarating experience.

The Russian uniforms are slightly more brown than grey. The German uniforms are slightly more grey than brown. They both bleed red explosively when you shoot them. They both fall suddenly with similar gurgled screams.

No other game has made me feel sorry for the people I kill, whether friendly or enemy.

If you like fast paced, run and gun shooters with plenty of explosions, don't get this game.

If you like waiting around, watching the same patch of landscape for a few minutes, changing position, repeating these steps, hiding from artillery, and then screaming through the most intense 10 second firefight of your life, get this game.

If you like quick respawns and CoD style self healing, don't get this game.

If you like having to bandage your wounds (if you manage to survive a bullet wound, a rare occurrence), or having to wait for your guy to calm down after a salvo flies past his head and reduces your comrade to mush before you can see properly again, get this game.

If you like hearing men cry for their mothers as they bleed to death beside you, get this game.


There's ballistic drop. There's an ammo counter that only keeps track of magazines. Your MG will overheat. You will be killed from 150m away without knowing how. You will feel tense whilst playing this game. I'm still not sure I enjoy it. But I keep coming back.

There is a slight problem on the odd server where people don't play the objective and that side pays the price quickly. But I don't think it's down to noob team members. Being in an objective zone is always brown trousers time. It takes courage to go in.

I mostly play the Red Orchestra maps, because both sides have bolt action rifles and there's a lot more urban warfare. To me it feels grittier.

There's nothing wrong with the Rising Storm maps.

It's just that playing as America, any amount of Japanese charging is terrifying, especially when you thought they were part of the bushes.

And playing as Japan... well, even I was screaming as I watched my hands melt in front of my eyes, cursing the flamethrower and every member of his family, past, present and future.

reviewText:
このゲームは往年のFPSとは一線を画するゲームである。

新兵となった君はチュートリアルもせずにマルチプレイヤーモードで適当な鯖に入って遊ぶ事になるだろう。
そして今まで培ったFPS技術が音を立てて崩れさった時、君はこのゲームに惚れるか、アンインストールして次の戦場に移っても良い。私は敗北主義者と罵って後ろから撃たないから

取り敢えずこのゲームはプレイヤーが貧弱であり、一発受けただけで大抵死ぬ。所謂リアリズムなゲームだ。立ってるだけで死ぬのだが、君が賢き者ならば今度リスポーンした時には「立っていると危ないからしゃがみながら行動しよう」と考える。
そういう次の戦闘に役立てる為に死んでいく事こそがこのゲームの醍醐味であり、このゲームでは立ち回りが非常に洗練されると、私は思う。

このゲームは悪い事ばかりではない。
このゲームのプレイヤーの肉体は貧弱だと言っていたが、それは自分だけではない。
相手も同じ立場なのだ。遠距離から不意打ちすれば相手は倒れる。
慣れたら前線に出て眼前の敵を殺したり殺されたり出来るようになれば、君は一人前の兵士であり、皆から信頼されるような心強い味方であり、敵にとっては悪魔のような存在になれるだろう。


購入を検討するのならライジングストームの方をオススメする。

【レッドオーケストラ2】
武器が万遍なく強く、お互いの力量が強い方が勝利に直結するし、タンク戦など独自の仕様がある。どちらも連射出来る武器が使えるし、高性能な狙撃銃が魅力的である。だがこれといって尖った武器がある訳ではなく、どちらを選んでも同じ様な強さを得る事が出来る。どの陣営を選んでも勝敗を明確に分けるものではない。

【ライジングストーム】
これはレッドオーケストラ2とは毛色が違う。まず日本と米軍に分かれて戦うのだが、史実を忠実に再現してしまったせいで、日本の攻める公式マップが(2014/7/31現在)3つしかない。
そしてレッドオーケストラ2とは違い武器の性能差が激しい。
まず米軍は歩兵レベルで半自動小銃が携行可能であるし、殆どが短機関銃や軽機関銃を携行可能だし、武器はかなり恵まれた状態でスタート出来る。なんといっても米軍にしか装備出来ない火炎放射器、この強力過ぎる武器は私も常々頭を悩ませる存在だ。これに関しては是非その悪魔の炎をその身体にうけて感じてほしい。

さて、比べて日本の武器ではあるが、殆どがボルトアクションライフルしか装備出来ず、連射性能がある武器といえば数が少なく、それでいて選べる数が少なすぎる。お世辞にも性能が良いとは言えない、米軍がeasyモードならば日本はhardモードでプレイみたいな感じと思ってもらっても構わない。米軍は適当にやってるだけで勝利出来るが、日本側は防衛戦が多すぎるせいで、知略の限りを尽くして防衛しなければならない。
しかし日本側も決して弱いだけではない。日本の兵士だけが使える「バンザイチャージ」これは使いようによっては戦線を一発で覆す性能を秘めている。
これは簡単に言えば「気合で能力を底上げする」であり、リスポン位置から遠い事で有名なガ島や速攻で戦地に戻らなければならない硫黄島のFなどですぐに舞い戻るにはこれを有効に活用しなければならない。

長くなりすぎたようだが、もしも君が普通のFPSに飽きていたのなら、新鮮さを求めるようにこの戦場に舞い降りて見ないだろうか？

reviewText:
Ah, Red Orchestra. Where do I even begin?

If I run from cover to cover, I get shredded by machinegun fire. If I peek my head to get a clear field of view, a sniper somewhere hears angels chanting and pierces my brains, splattering the wall behind me.

This game is hard, nerve-wracking, and not for the faint of heart or anyone who is used to 1337 720ºNoscopesnipah kills.
This game encourages camping.
This game is like a severe parent punishing your every mistake.
This game is absolutely, bloody good. Get it if you can. Play it if you have the time. I know I only clocked around 20 hours on it, but I would play the hell out of it if I could.

So, let us get serious.

Hardcore shooter with cover mechanics. Somewhat glitchy, too, but I don't find it unplayable by any means. Servers are typically 32 vs 32, with bots usually filling any slots left (which gives both teams an impressive amount of cannon fodder), so you know the battles are going to be big.
Weapons lack variety, which is to be expected considering it aims to be a realistic, historically-accurate game. And, bear with me here, said weapons are unbalanced. Remember COD 2? A semi-auto rifle will never, or hardly ever, one-hit kill, which is understandable for gameplay reasons. Cue Red Orchestra's Elite Rifleman class, armed with a semi-auto rifle: it has the same power as the humble breech-loading basic rifles, but is semi-auto and holds more ammo. Then again, it's limited to, say, 3 per team. Same happens with the LMG, with astonishing firepower, or the SMGs, which can make mincemeat of anything at close to medium ranges.

However, this not only means that there are, naturally, players better equipped. Those same players have responsibilities: take a marksman rifle and go lone wolf scoring random kills? Wrong. Use it to clear the way for a capture point, to find the machine gunner who is tearing your team apart. Squad leader? Stay alive to allow respawning on you, make judicious use of your smoke grenades. So on and so on. Teamplay is king. Armies win wars.

The cover system works well. You can sprint crouched. Grenades can be gently dropped instead of having to throw them at the ceiling hoping they stay in the damned room. Gunplay is smooth, graphics are really good, sound and effects immersive as it gets. What more is there to ask for?

Ah, yes. Satisfaction. The satisfaction of out-aiming an enemy 120 metres away. Looking at the top right corner, those seconds lying in wait, thinking Did I get him?". Then you see it. You hit him spot on
date: you got the kill. You may get pistol-whipped to death a second after
recommended: but getting a kill in Red Orchestra is as satisfying as it gets in a shooter.\n\nOf course
hoursPlayed: there are shortcomings. Optimization is poor. Some glitches can get a bit annoying. As I said
voteText: weapon variety is low and you may get relegated to basic Rifleman for rounds on end. You will get frustrated. The game is punishingly hard. But in the end
helpfulPercent: this is a top-notch shooter. Go get it. Go get 'em."

reviewText:
I got this game for free. Its okay. Nothing special. 90% of populated server run realism, so no hud so if you're new you're screwed, and everyone has most guns fully leveled or w/e and most servers limit classes so you're usually stuck in as a rifleman. It reminds me of COD 2 because the rifle play is good (but stuck as rifleman for map after map, isn't that fun after a while) and that game was fun, but its slow loading (UE3 isn't this slow but this game loads slow even on a nice rig) and limited servers makes it really hard to get into.

I'd still buy it as its really one of the few that is a decent FPS now-a-days but I come from Arma, CoD, BF, CS, etc FPS's so if you havent played RO1 or dont like realism/hc all the time its probably not a great fit unless you want some challenge.

7/10

reviewText: A WWII shooter that plays from both the Russian and the Pacific fronts where players can side with either faction. Most of the games you will end up joining will use the realism system where you pretty much die in one shot and there is no crosshair for you to aim with. It all comes down to which team works together more, how well you use your iron sights, and how well your team knows their own kits. Rising Storm is the newer game that came out recently that added Japan vs USA in the pacific fronts giving new weapons, maps, and classes at the player's disposal. It is a fun game, but at times I can see why it can be so frustrating when your team fails to work together.

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 isn't just another first-person shooter, It's an experience that brings new life to a genre that has been done a thousand times before.

Giving both a realistic and immersive experience of World War 2. You must think carefully about your every action and is one of the only games that gives the feeling that you're just a single soldier out of a whole platoon and not some superhero who can win on their own, with every game requiring teamwork and communication to win.

But what really makes this game truly unique and shine is its impressive use of many different historical accuracies of World War 2 that are normally left out or aren’t attempted in games. From the smaller things like the way the soldiers hold their guns while running with the Germans and Japanese holding their guns in only one hand and the Germans and Americans holding theirs with both. And the bigger things like the way banzai charges were implemented. Theres nothing that gets your heart racing more than the other team banzai charing across the battlefield towards you.

Though the game may take getting used to, as it’s a different experience to other first-person shooters on the market, It’s well worth spending the time getting the hang of it and putting a good chunk of time into with some mates.

reviewText:
このゲームは往年のFPSとは一線を画するゲームである。

新兵となった君はチュートリアルもせずにマルチプレイヤーモードで適当な鯖に入って遊ぶ事になるだろう。
そして今まで培ったFPS技術が音を立てて崩れさった時、君はこのゲームに惚れるか、アンインストールして次の戦場に移っても良い。私は敗北主義者と罵って後ろから撃たないから

取り敢えずこのゲームはプレイヤーが貧弱であり、一発受けただけで大抵死ぬ。所謂リアリズムなゲームだ。立ってるだけで死ぬのだが、君が賢き者ならば今度リスポーンした時には「立っていると危ないからしゃがみながら行動しよう」と考える。
そういう次の戦闘に役立てる為に死んでいく事こそがこのゲームの醍醐味であり、このゲームでは立ち回りが非常に洗練されると、私は思う。

このゲームは悪い事ばかりではない。
このゲームのプレイヤーの肉体は貧弱だと言っていたが、それは自分だけではない。
相手も同じ立場なのだ。遠距離から不意打ちすれば相手は倒れる。
慣れたら前線に出て眼前の敵を殺したり殺されたり出来るようになれば、君は一人前の兵士であり、皆から信頼されるような心強い味方であり、敵にとっては悪魔のような存在になれるだろう。


購入を検討するのならライジングストームの方をオススメする。

【レッドオーケストラ2】
武器が万遍なく強く、お互いの力量が強い方が勝利に直結するし、タンク戦など独自の仕様がある。どちらも連射出来る武器が使えるし、高性能な狙撃銃が魅力的である。だがこれといって尖った武器がある訳ではなく、どちらを選んでも同じ様な強さを得る事が出来る。どの陣営を選んでも勝敗を明確に分けるものではない。

【ライジングストーム】
これはレッドオーケストラ2とは毛色が違う。まず日本と米軍に分かれて戦うのだが、史実を忠実に再現してしまったせいで、日本の攻める公式マップが(2014/7/31現在)3つしかない。
そしてレッドオーケストラ2とは違い武器の性能差が激しい。
まず米軍は歩兵レベルで半自動小銃が携行可能であるし、殆どが短機関銃や軽機関銃を携行可能だし、武器はかなり恵まれた状態でスタート出来る。なんといっても米軍にしか装備出来ない火炎放射器、この強力過ぎる武器は私も常々頭を悩ませる存在だ。これに関しては是非その悪魔の炎をその身体にうけて感じてほしい。

さて、比べて日本の武器ではあるが、殆どがボルトアクションライフルしか装備出来ず、連射性能がある武器といえば数が少なく、それでいて選べる数が少なすぎる。お世辞にも性能が良いとは言えない、米軍がeasyモードならば日本はhardモードでプレイみたいな感じと思ってもらっても構わない。米軍は適当にやってるだけで勝利出来るが、日本側は防衛戦が多すぎるせいで、知略の限りを尽くして防衛しなければならない。
しかし日本側も決して弱いだけではない。日本の兵士だけが使える「バンザイチャージ」これは使いようによっては戦線を一発で覆す性能を秘めている。
これは簡単に言えば「気合で能力を底上げする」であり、リスポン位置から遠い事で有名なガ島や速攻で戦地に戻らなければならない硫黄島のFなどですぐに舞い戻るにはこれを有効に活用しなければならない。

長くなりすぎたようだが、もしも君が普通のFPSに飽きていたのなら、新鮮さを求めるようにこの戦場に舞い降りて見ないだろうか？

reviewText:
Initially I though this was going to be a big disappointment  because the boot camp portion of the game  looked rather retro. The weapons looked like   games I'd purchased   several years ago.  The boot camp wasn't challenging at all and each weapon station didn't give you enough time to get a feel for the various weapons available in the game.  (The first boot camp I ever played  via the first  Medal of Honor  was better); however on starting the campain proper I was really pleased to find this was  a very well made game.  It's not  Call of Duty, but   there was somthing about the game mechanics that drew me in.  Weapons are   fairly basic, my favorite being the sniper rifle.

If you love run and gun games this isn't for you.  You  need to  use cover sensibly as often as possible or you'll keep dying.  When you die you  take over one of your squad mates (in singleplayer).  It was well worth  the full price I paid for it.

Looking forwards to some community based mods for this game.

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 isn't just another first-person shooter, It's an experience that brings new life to a genre that has been done a thousand times before.

Giving both a realistic and immersive experience of World War 2. You must think carefully about your every action and is one of the only games that gives the feeling that you're just a single soldier out of a whole platoon and not some superhero who can win on their own, with every game requiring teamwork and communication to win.

But what really makes this game truly unique and shine is its impressive use of many different historical accuracies of World War 2 that are normally left out or aren’t attempted in games. From the smaller things like the way the soldiers hold their guns while running with the Germans and Japanese holding their guns in only one hand and the Germans and Americans holding theirs with both. And the bigger things like the way banzai charges were implemented. Theres nothing that gets your heart racing more than the other team banzai charing across the battlefield towards you.

Though the game may take getting used to, as it’s a different experience to other first-person shooters on the market, It’s well worth spending the time getting the hang of it and putting a good chunk of time into with some mates.

reviewText:
This game is really, really good, besides a few issues.

Pros:
-Tactical, gritty and definitely realistic, you will find yourself in a constant state of anticipation, not knowing if your next step will be your last, especially since the spawn is actually extremely broken (that part is a con)
-Guns feel and sound absolutely amazing and powerful (M1 Garand unf)
-No shortage of realism servers, as a matter of fact there are no casual servers in the server browser
-Extremely unforgiving, you die in one or two shots.
-Suspensful, and very fun to play.
-A great sense of community and teamwork (A big plus!)
-Maps are large, with a good balance between urban, open and close quarters combat.
-Graphics are okay for a Unreal game.

Cons:
-Spawn is legitmately broken as ef u see kay
-No, seriously, it's bad.
-No spawn protection.
-Not a very wide variety of weapons
-Can give you shingles from stress
-Really the only con with this game is the lack of playerbase and the spawn.


I haven't played much RO to make a meaningful comparion, but it is a worthy successor overall. I highly suggest this game if you're tired of Call of Duty and Battlefield.

reviewText:
A fun, actually realistic stratergy Multiplayer shooting game

This game offers a immense soundtrack and theme, with beautiful looking maps

Only downside is the community, half of it is amazing and one of the best i have found, the other? Extreme racism and slander from casuals at all fronts, but finding a good reliable server to regular on solves everything.

The game actually offers a rather interesting leveling up system, what rewards you well with every game through unlocks.

Bugs are still everywhere, but none of them are big or game breaking, just minor and hardly worth noting.

The game delivers extremely smooth optimisation and frames at all ranges on every map, no spikes regardless of 10 players or 64 players and dozens of mortars....

Overall 8/10, Great to see the franchise Progressing so well, without selling out!

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad with the paid DLC Rising Storm.  If you like World War 2 themed PVP first person shooter simulations, this is a good game to get.  This game is slightly less realistic than the original Red Orchestra, but the graphics and the gameplay is whole lot better.  The single player is WW2 combat like the original Call of Duty and Medal of Honor games.  Comes with a separate Singleplayer campaign game.

You can play as infantry or tanker only.  The tank combat here is better than the original Red Orchestra, because the tank crew bots listen to your detailed comands that you can give, and you have more viewports to use.  The tanks models looks limited to the Panzer 4 and T-34 in the few original tank using maps.  As Commander, you can issue useful commands to your teammates.

Server Maps can have AI bots filling out the team roster.  You can command the bots squads to take objectives, defend objectives, or go to locations but not give artillery targets.  The bots are slightly more smarter, and have better shooting skills but still no substitute for real players.

RO2 multiplayer servers are German vs Russian maps.  With the Rising Storm DLC you have access to Japan vs American maps, (Using the Flamethrower is fun).  Has great multiplayer maps and a single person campaign.  A lot of multiplayer servers have bots filling in for real players.

The single player campaigns are German vs Russian or Russian vs German, it is a separate game bundled with your purchase.  The single player game is sort of buggy and cheats.  You can also use console comands in the single player game to complete the achievements there.

Has Steam Achievements with badge trading cards. Has Steam Workshop with modding community making new maps using the included Level Editor.

reviewText:
Cons:
-Great WWII shooter in a market saturated by shooters like Call of Duty and Battlefield
-The Eastern Front portion of the game is extremely well balanced with the Germans having an edge in machine guns, authomatic rifles and pistols but with the Russians having the edge in Submachineguns, tanks and the  Urah charge.
-Historically accurate, rare for any shooter
-Very mature community
-Nonrepititive gameplay that will allow one to sink hours into it without it being bored whatsoever.
-Killing is very rewarding in the game, I have no idea why.
-Includes the Pacific Theatre of War
-Multiple vehicle classes such as the half-track, lighttank and medium tank.
-Great system of leveling up
-The ability to mod
-Great for cheaper systems.

Cons:
-Game can be a pain in the ♥♥♥ to run sometimes, program prone to not responding
-The American forces are OP compared to the Japanese, which they're always fighting unless you have mods.
-Lack of servers and players.
-Too many veteran ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s on the game that act like they're in charge of everything because they've been to Iraq or whatever
-They didn't include Heavy tanks in the game
-The maps are massive but only in one regard. For example, the map Bridges of Druzhina" is probably 3 kilometers long but only .5 wide. Same with Red October Factory and Spartanovka. More "square" maps should have been implemented!
-Too much coordination between team members needed to enjoy the game. It's pretty common to have one team stomping on the other because a new player has taken the commander slot and refuses to give it up. Same with the squad leaders who are supposed to be mobile spawn points but you always have people getting their heads blown off.

7.5/10
Could have been better

reviewText: To best summarize RO2/RS I'll start with a story. We were Russians defending some lowly Grain Elevator in the middle of no where. The Germans were crushing us with relentless force. I had managed to flank the Germans and I saw a German crouched behind a wall. I ran up and hit him with the butt of my rifle because bullets are a luxury in mother russia. As he stood there screaming for his mother I realized that he and were both part of something much larger that us. A war that neither of us understood but we still fought even though we were not so different.  Then I got MP40 sniped for 100m away.\n\n10/10 would set my team on fire again.

reviewText: Red Orchestra 2 / Rising Storm is a must for anyone who enjoys a WWII FPS that rewards team work. The game has superb map design and makes good use of its realistic damage and ballistics models. That being said, it is certainly a steep learning curve for those coming from the likes of CoD or BF where it takes near a full magazine to get a kill; accuracy is hard to achieve and it can be hard to differentiate friend from foe.\n\nAll in all, RO2/RS is a superb buy for those who are willing to put the time into getting used to it and few other games reward teamwork as much.

reviewText:
Probably one of my all-time favourite FPS games that I've played to date.  Red Orchestra keeps bringing me back because it's a hardcore first-person shooter that requires skill, tactics and patience to achieve victory. Although a heavy team based game, your actions alone can determine whether your team lose or win; it is your choice on how you approach the enemy and defeat them.

The best thing about Tripwire Interactive is that they don't create ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. No OP weapons, no OP glitches, no cheating/hacking. Just satisfying, hardcore gameplay.

Definitely a must if you enjoy World War II, team based gameplay with a heavy involvement in tactics and team communication.

reviewText: Guadlcanal, August 1942\nAfter the landing i was promoted to squad leader. It was some time in the middle of the night when we heard those cans go off. We knew the Japs where coming. My squad Mike, Jackson, Billy, Jake, and Caleb set up firing positions. We waited the tensions grew i knew it was over when i heard Banzaiii!." out of the darkness they came i was never so scared in my life. I lit them up with my Thompson. it was to let they breached our lines they were all around us. I ordered my squad to fall back to the bunker we did. They rest of the base was up and ready to fight. I asked mike to make a run to the commander. He only made it 10 feet before he was shot. we threw nades then i popped smoke and we ran to the red cross station we didn't hold out for long we fell back to the next point i only had 2 mags left. We killed Japs left
recommended: and centre. Jake was standing next to me when a bullet went though his head. I was down to my pistol Bill and Caleb where in the bunker behind me about 4ft away. I was about to make a run to them when 4 Japs Charged bayonets coming at me. I fired an entire mag only killing one. The Japs stuck me through and through. Bill and Caleb shot the Japs and ran over to me . It was to late i had already bleed out... Sgt BlackJack Guadlcanal 1942

reviewText:
Probably one of my all-time favourite FPS games that I've played to date.  Red Orchestra keeps bringing me back because it's a hardcore first-person shooter that requires skill, tactics and patience to achieve victory. Although a heavy team based game, your actions alone can determine whether your team lose or win; it is your choice on how you approach the enemy and defeat them.

The best thing about Tripwire Interactive is that they don't create ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. No OP weapons, no OP glitches, no cheating/hacking. Just satisfying, hardcore gameplay.

Definitely a must if you enjoy World War II, team based gameplay with a heavy involvement in tactics and team communication.

reviewText:
One of the best FPS games of all time.
Strongly recommend to those who love realistic shooters. A truly great game.

Pros:
+ Good game mechanics (squads, objectives, team tickets (lives), artillery support, etc.)
+ Death in 1 or 2 shots
+ Accurate weapons usage
+ Tactical reloading does not magically result in full magazines
+ Chambered rounds are taken into account
+ Ability to roughly check how many rounds are left in a mag (more than half full, etc.)
+ Weapon resting (including sideways along window frames, walls, poles, or wherever)
+ Breathing rate directly (synchronized) affects vertical weapon movement
+ Suppression/morale system
+ Well-designed, fairly large maps
+ Accurate hitboxes
+ Bullet drop, not sure how accurate it is though
+ Some tanks and APCs
+ Ability to manually bolt, increases gun feeling, and allows to keep looking through scope
+ Only scope area zooms in, not the entire screen
+ Can switch to iron sights on some scoped rifles
+ Can swap hot barrel for MG
+ Can disable focusing zoom, and if you choose to keep zooming enabled, it is very minimal
+ On some servers, friendly player names are only shown at very close ranges
+ Can choose to manually reload when empty
+ Can change firing mode
+ Nice, actually recorded, gun sounds

Cons:
- Recoil isn't quite right
- Unrealistic sounds of bullets passing by (fake swoosh sounds or, less commonly, extremely quiet cracks". The suppression system helps alleviate this con
date: though).\n- Punkbuster (but many servers now run VAC instead
recommended: so you don't need to have PB installed)\n-Would be much better with positional voice chat"

votesHelpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad / Rising Storm GOTY

Pros:
- Immersion, immersion, immersion
- No biased point of view ( A rare thing in WWII games )
- Good gameplay
- Good AI

Many people have commented on this game being a PTSD Simulator". This claim is far from unjustified. This game is super-immersive ( Even more so when using the Immersion Overhaul Simulator - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/IOMMODplayers ). Realistic graphics
recommended:
suppression affects and an amazing atmosphere of constant danger give this game an edge over other WWII games of the genre.

No biased Point of View is another big tick for me. No more evil Germans or unbalanced mechanics that impact how the Germans play. This is a big step forward and a great way of seeing how the front was ACTUALLY LIKE. No more of the lies made up about the Germans by the victors.

Gameplay strives to be as realistic as possible
hoursPlayed: while also catering to beginners. Most weapons take one shot to kill
voteText: but are balanced by accuracy and weapon sway
helpfulPercent:
etc. Tank gameplay is extremely impressive with full internal views and great combat elements.

The AI are not easy to say the least. They are only slightly less competent than a human player. There are also always servers with lots of bots to practice with.

Cons:
- Flamethrowers...
- Banned From Session

Flamethrowers on this game are fairly unbalaced - and only one nation
votesHelpful: the US
votesTotal: gets them. They can be taken out from range
votesFunny: but will take down several people before dying. Not the biggest issue
commentsCount: but definitely something to look out for.\n\nThere is a possibility that you will be banned from a server for the rest of a session (battle) for having high ping. There is no proper way of fixing this
column16: just join servers with good connection unless you want to take your chances on other servers.\n\n*P.S: I play on Oceania ( servers and setups may vary )"

reviewText: My favourite WWII shooter that I have ever played, from a multiplayer perspective. The intensity and detail of the game, from the weapons, uniforms/equipment etc, more than make up for the lack of large maps and variety of vehicles that Ostfront had. RO2 itself is a pleasure to play and in my experience has a very mature community. It's always fun to jump into. Once on a good server, the combat and communication between team mates make for an intense, exhilirating and/or frustrating (Depending on who's winning) scenario. I recommend this game for anynone who likes gritty and unforgiving WWII shooters where no ammo counter or crosshair is present (Unless you play action mode), the realism mode is where this game stands out. The free aim system is a big plus, and the detail is excellent right down to the animations and weapon models, which even have adjustable iron sights. The implementation of recoil, and the suppression system work very well to reduce the effectiveness of a pinned sniper and spray and prayer types.\n\n9.5/10 - Great Game, especially when you have a squad of friends on the go.

reviewText:
This game is really cool if you like lying behind some cover with a mounted MG shooting the crap into Russians.

You can be on the Russian side or the German side, they are both pretty cool, for the Russians, you get a PPSH with other rifles like the Mosin-Nagnant, snipers etc, for the Germans, you get MP40's, MG's, snipers, rifles and so on.

I would also recommend getting the Rising Storm, as you can be a Japanese soldier or an American soldier. The Japanese get the have Katanas and the Americans get the have flamethrowers which is a pretty fun boost from Red Orchestra 2.

The graphics are a bit outdated, maybe similar to Call of Duty: World at War, but it is still better than that game. Also, if you have a screen resolution of 1360 x 768 like myself, you'll have to play the game in a windowed mode because of the screen resolution being stretched etc.

The modes are also really good because you can go to 'Realism Mode' which is like 1 bullet death, so it's realistic. (unlike COD)

Seriously, get Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad, even if you haven't seen it because you will not be disappointed.

reviewText:
An amazing game, probably my favourite multiplayer online FPS and certainly one of the best war games ever made. Experience amazing, exciting battles where teamwork is key, classes actually matter and tactics take a huge role in the matches final outcome.

The graphics are still very good, the game runs quite smoothly and has been polished throughout the last few years, now being complete with the Rising Storm expansion that improves upon this already amazing game with a more versatile, action oriented gameplay without losing it's realist focus.

There are stats and stat rewards to keep you going, none of them making the game unbalanced but giving you slight advantages over low level players that actually make for a very interesting, rewarding progression system.

It's an amazing game, and i'd recomend it any day.

9.5/10

reviewText: Ever wanted to feel on the front? Know what is on the mind of a WW2 frontline soldier/officer/commander on the German/Russian side? Well, here's your chance. the most realistic WW2 FPS game you can find is here, not your regular fps where you can get what you want, here, you will get what they give you, for instance, do you think the germans made enough mp-40 submachineguns for ALL their soldiers? NO! only officers could have them, so you my friend, is probably gonna get a kar98 bolt action rifle. THE REAL MAN'S RIFLE, to see if you are as skilled as a german soldier. Think of it as a real life challenge: most players have rifles that require skill to shoot, some have submachineguns, some have lightmachineguns and just a few have sniper rifles, so running may be a good idea, togheter with hiding on cover, but keep in mind that you are not alone and team tactics are the welcome, togheter with officers using microphones to tell you the strategy. You want a real man's game or a baby's fps? Make your choice.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A fun, actually realistic stratergy Multiplayer shooting game

This game offers a immense soundtrack and theme, with beautiful looking maps

Only downside is the community, half of it is amazing and one of the best i have found, the other? Extreme racism and slander from casuals at all fronts, but finding a good reliable server to regular on solves everything.

The game actually offers a rather interesting leveling up system, what rewards you well with every game through unlocks.

Bugs are still everywhere, but none of them are big or game breaking, just minor and hardly worth noting.

The game delivers extremely smooth optimisation and frames at all ranges on every map, no spikes regardless of 10 players or 64 players and dozens of mortars....

Overall 8/10, Great to see the franchise Progressing so well, without selling out!

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad / Rising Storm GOTY

Pros:
- Immersion, immersion, immersion
- No biased point of view ( A rare thing in WWII games )
- Good gameplay
- Good AI

Many people have commented on this game being a PTSD Simulator". This claim is far from unjustified. This game is super-immersive ( Even more so when using the Immersion Overhaul Simulator - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/IOMMODplayers ). Realistic graphics
recommended:
suppression affects and an amazing atmosphere of constant danger give this game an edge over other WWII games of the genre.

No biased Point of View is another big tick for me. No more evil Germans or unbalanced mechanics that impact how the Germans play. This is a big step forward and a great way of seeing how the front was ACTUALLY LIKE. No more of the lies made up about the Germans by the victors.

Gameplay strives to be as realistic as possible
hoursPlayed: while also catering to beginners. Most weapons take one shot to kill
voteText: but are balanced by accuracy and weapon sway
helpfulPercent:
etc. Tank gameplay is extremely impressive with full internal views and great combat elements.

The AI are not easy to say the least. They are only slightly less competent than a human player. There are also always servers with lots of bots to practice with.

Cons:
- Flamethrowers...
- Banned From Session

Flamethrowers on this game are fairly unbalaced - and only one nation
votesHelpful: the US
votesTotal: gets them. They can be taken out from range
votesFunny: but will take down several people before dying. Not the biggest issue
commentsCount: but definitely something to look out for.\n\nThere is a possibility that you will be banned from a server for the rest of a session (battle) for having high ping. There is no proper way of fixing this
column16: just join servers with good connection unless you want to take your chances on other servers.\n\n*P.S: I play on Oceania ( servers and setups may vary )"

reviewText:
-Everyone on my team forms up behind a wall as we prepare to charge towards soviet-occupied building

-Our commander talks to the squad leaders for at least five minutes to discuss how we will take the building

-One squad leader says that it will be impossible to even reach the building entrance because of how far it is

-He gets shot for defeatism

-I get appointed SL as his replacement

-Commander briefs me quickly on what he wants my squad to do

-Everyone gets pumped up as we prepare to take the building for the fatherland

-Commander orders everyone to charge

-Everyone charges and I watch 20 of my teammates get mowed down by Soviet MG fire

-My squad is the only one that reached the building

-We move in slowly and everyone gets nervous because there are no soviets in sight

-We climb up to the second floor and kill the soviet machingunner

-We win the match because we killed all of their players

-I check the scoreboard

-Turns out he was the only guy defending the building and that we had killed the rest of their players prior to our charge

10/10 Would get PTSD because of one Communist again

reviewText:
Red Orchestra 2 is an FPS game set during World War II and more precisely during the conquer of Stalingrad by the German army: during the single player campaign we will play first as a German soldier on the attacking side and then as a Russian soldier and his team who has to defend various location in Stalingrad from the German attack. Overall the story and the story-telling are good, but the low performance optimization, the bad A.I. and a bunch of bugs really make the singleplayer experience worse than it should be.

On the multiplayer side this game really shines, all the problems of the singleplayer were fixed, good graphics and performance, less bugs and good A.I. The tactical and realistic style that this game has is really hard to find in other videogames, i can only compare it to a mix of Arma and BattleField mechanics: lots of different classes with actually different roles, vehicles, covers, medium/large-sized maps (but smaller then Arma or BF), character and weapons experience levels and a realistic game mode in which you die with a single rifle shot or a small assault rifle burst.

At the beginning the game can look hard and not appealing but once you get to know the basics and the mechanics you will start to love it: for this i suggest everyone to play the campaign first, even if it's the worse part of the game, that will help you enjoy the multiplayer.

In less words, BUY IT.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
DayZ indoctrinated me to the realistic shooters out there. Red Orchestra 2, while not as robust as the ArmA series, has nailed so many aspects of the gritty, unprejudiced realities of war that these soldiers had gone through. Machine guns prey on on potentially dozens of enemies if caught unaware. The sheer imbalance of close quarters and the impractibility of being in the open for even short amounts of time prove how fragile your life is. Squad tactics become important and smoke grenades, explosives, and covering fire become essential when taking objectives. Artillery can wipe out nearly all the members of a team in just once strike and seeminly good cover can prove fatal when a stray bullet pierces your helmet. When one life is so meaningless you cherish it for some reason, nobody wants to be the one to cross the machine gun nest's field of vision, or the sniper that is watching for your slightest mistake. Your life becomes valuable despite it seemingly not being so. Your participation in capturing objectives can make or break a game, however. Teamwork and leadership wins the majority of games through good squad leaders and a good team leader. Red Orchestra 2 is a realism shooter for the hardcore, but is accessible to anyone just looking for an intense, but good time.

Its not perfect. Certain angles with the prone system are abused, but this is very, very rare. Sometimes the cover system in the game messes with your ability to bandage yourself (they share a key) and you die a needless death. This is slightly less rare, but it doesn't happen often. Also against players the cover system is rarely worth it. Exiting cover in the system to shoot is often a sure way to die quickly as you expose an awful lot of your body while doing so. Melee combat is often not perfect and for some reason servers that display 50 ping in the browser sometimes gives everyone 200 ping in game. These are all very minor, however, and do not affect the game much. Its certainly less annoying than certain things in Call of Duty, Battlefield, and ArmA. Counter Strike Source (or GO) is much more polished but that is a very different game so I wouldn't compare the two.

Rising Storm, the standalone expansion (you dont need the base game to play) is like a whole new game. The large, open areas and bombed out ruins of the Eastern Front are replaced with the dense jungle of the Pacific Isles and despite some similar sized maps, the battles are closer and even more intense. It becomes even more brutal despite the absence of tanks as it becomes very clear, very quickly, the Japanese forces are at a disadvantage. The force multiplier the Allies rely on are provided by larger machine gun belts, semi-automatic rifles, powerful sub-machine guns and support weapons, and flamethrowers that can take out entire squads with a bursting swath of fiery death. This forces Japanese to abuse their mechanics of knee-mortars and banzai charges or overwhelmingly lose any given match. Often, banzai charges make the difference between a win and a loss in a match and melee combat is a much more common occurance than in RO2:HoS, further amplifying the brutality of the close quarters, unfair, Pacific Front.

Together you have two amazing takes on war that doesn't feed on its own ridiculousness or cheesy one-off matches of quick entertainment. The campaign system gives some meaning to playing on your favorite servers with your favorite communities and following the lead of a good squad leader (while contributing) is a sure way to make some fast friends. The community is very mature as kids tend to avoid the difficult learning curve of the game but once you get into it, learn the maps, the guns, and the basics of realism, it will really grow on you. Listen to the veterans and you'll stay alive.

reviewText: A solid World War II experience with many realistic aspects such as bullet range calibration for different firearms and vehicles, bleeding out unless bandaged, and a large bundle of war-torn maps as one would expect from when the war was at it's worst. A great multiplayer system, hosting is simple and joining is simpler than it was in the first game, maps support up to 64 players total, allowing for 32 players on each side playing as either the Axis or Allied forces.\n\nOverall, this game gets a score of 8/10 due to a somewhat flonky controll system and the occational framerate and bug issues. Some aspects in the game should've been more polished such as the cover mechanics and bullet damage. (The hardcore mode fixes this to some extent, although it still lingers with some firearms).

reviewText:
-Excellent gameplay if you enjoy realism and team cooperation in a WWII FPS
-One bullet is enough to kill you on most parts of the body, otherwise you're probably going to need to bandage your wounds. Bandages are scarce.
-Good cover system, similar to Call of Juarez's allowing you to aim where you wish over or around cover. I don't use it too much honestly.
-Suppression system: If you keep fire on an enemy position (even just firing over them, not necessarily hitting them) they will not be able to move or fire back.
-Slightly annoying-to-use squad/command system, which is neglected by players a lot unfortunately
-Very good acoustics(?) on the weapons. As you move to or from a source of gunfire you can hear the change in sound. At a distance of a few hundred metres it sounds as though it could just be ambient (non-player controlled) noise recorded at a shooting range, which is nice.
-Great voice acting, unfortunately there are only two different voices per team. That isn't much of a problem anyway, they don't get stale.
-Decent music, although it's only ambient.
-Extremely good tank gameplay, especially if you're coordinating with a friend(s). I haven't used the Soviet T-34s, but there are 4 positions in the Panzer IV which can either be operated all by one person, or as a group with other players. There's only one tank-only map I've played so far, which I thought there should be more of.
-Lastly, due to a combination of a few previously mentioned things (acoustics, music, gameplay, voice-acting), the environment is one of the things I like most aside from gameplay. On most maps it's very gloomy and dark, with massive barrages of artillery and dog-fights overhead. This combined with the dreary layout of the map (abandoned buildings, train-lines, trenches, etc.), ambient music and constant gunshots makes Stalingrad feel like Stalingrad.
-Rising Storm is mediocre, not many people playing it in Australia either.

Not a whole lot of negatives to the game, movement and some other actions can feel a bit clunky at times. There is a losing bias to the Axis I've noticed recently, I have a win/loss ratio of 0.08 (~80 wins, ~900 losses), yet a kill/death ratio of 1.1 (not implying that's a good ratio, just that it's not terribly [game-losingly] bad). I'm not sure whether this is due to the Axis being inherently underpowered, or veteran players always choosing to play as the Allies. I'd therefore recommend sticking to the Allies if you're new.

reviewText:
It was December 1942, I was ordered by high command to assault the railway station we lost to the Nazis. My fellow comrades, nervous in the cold looked to me for inspiration. Finally after a brutal battle we retook the station and stopping for a single day, we continued towards the Russian front.

Excerpts from Lt. Col Grigory Chekov, On the Russian Front"

reviewText:
Drawing your katana, a glorious hope and honour to the Emperor fills your mind. The men around you ready their bayonets for a charge that will bring glory to the Japanese empire. The American scum, your sworn enemy, advance forward with automatic weaponry and flamethrowers. But you have cold steel and a fire raging in your heart. You position your katana for a killing blow, stand up and...

TENNO HEIKA, BANZAI!

A roaring of heavy machine gun fire, warmth on your face from a jet of burning flamethrower fuel, the crack of grenades, thumping mortar impacts, steel clashing, men screaming... And then it's all over in one M1 shot to the head.

reviewText:
This game, wow. This game is stunning.

Based on real battles of World War 2, this game strives for realism. It succeeds.

This game is also very tactical, so if you're a fan of game series such as Call of Duty or Battlefield you're not in luck if you want to run in and kill every living thing that shows up on your minimap.

First of all, there's no minimap in Red Orchestra 2, (this is all based on Realism gameplay) so you really have to use your initiative to find enemies.

Second, there's the choice of many classes. Also, different maps have different teams. Axis being the Japanese and Germans, Allies being the Russians or Americans.

Unfortunately, the British do not feature in this game. Neither does America Vs Japanese battles.

If you're a fan of realistic, fun, tactical war games this is definitely an essential.

reviewText: Everyone gather around with our squad leader about the charge we were about to do.  Our squad leader is supposed to throw the smoke granade and everyone charging at their position. As soon as smoke poped we stood up and started running. My friend got shot to his leg and started bleeding. He used all of his bandages and couldn't do anything. I stopped charging, turned around and decided to spend the last moments with him. It lasted about 7 second but to me it was years. Full of anger I started charging, screaming knowing I would die. I started firing my weapon like crazy and actually killing one. Continuing charging to our position then all of the sudden I got shot. So many thoughts went trough my head. I started crying. Then I heard my friends voice. I got all mad all of the sudden and continued tocharge. Screaming while bleeding with stops to shoot lasted for short time. Then It happend. My time has come. My vision was blurry, losing my hearing and slowly falling. I know I was dying and accepted it. But I know I died for something. Something that was forth fighting for\n\n1337/10 best avenging friend game ever!!!

reviewText: A solid World War II experience with many realistic aspects such as bullet range calibration for different firearms and vehicles, bleeding out unless bandaged, and a large bundle of war-torn maps as one would expect from when the war was at it's worst. A great multiplayer system, hosting is simple and joining is simpler than it was in the first game, maps support up to 64 players total, allowing for 32 players on each side playing as either the Axis or Allied forces.\n\nOverall, this game gets a score of 8/10 due to a somewhat flonky controll system and the occational framerate and bug issues. Some aspects in the game should've been more polished such as the cover mechanics and bullet damage. (The hardcore mode fixes this to some extent, although it still lingers with some firearms).

reviewText:
The most realistic first person shooter I've ever played. Quite the learning curve I find but once you get the hang of it, this can be one awesome game. Gravity has effect on the bullets, but you can adjust sights to compensate for distance, you can rest your rifle against a window sill or door ledge to stable your firearm for accuracy, controls inside the tanks are in view, and there's effects for when you're under suppressive fire. You can also level up classes and firearms to become more efficient. Not terribly unlike real life, after all you can condition yourself to have better stamina, get more in tune with the firearms you own, and you can also get attachments/modifications for some. Hoping that in Red Orchestra 3, they incorporate the possibility of jams. In real life however, if you maintain your firearms, malfunctions will be few and far between. No gun is 100% reliable, though. Not even AKs or Glocks.


June 23, 2014 - Since an update they made in April, I have been unable to play the game, and many others have also been unable to join servers. Do not waste your money on RO2 or RS until it starts working again, it will only give you headaches.

Nov 24, 2014 - The issue seems to have been resolved, the game is running well again. Enjoy the WWII realism!

reviewText:
So, after playing the multiplayer of both Rising Storm & Red Orchestra 2 for about 170+ hours and reaching max level on Rising Storm while also reaching a decently high level on Red Orchestra 2, I can say that this game is excellent.

The game is extremely unforgiving, you often die in pretty much 1 or 2 hits. If you are hit anywhere but your limbs, you'll probably die instantly. The only times you really have a chance to survive is if a bullet hits your arm or leg. If you somehow don't die instantly and you're wounded, you can use one of the 2 bandages you are given every spawn to patch yourself up. If you do not bandage up in time, you might bleed out depending on where you got shot. It is very important to move carefully by going from cover to cover and checking your corners.

I really like the fact that there's a max player limit per class, for example, there are only allowed to be a set amount of Assault class" players
hoursPlayed: squad leader etc... The only class that is really never full is rifleman. Which makes sense

helpfulPercent: the enemies often drops quite realistically which makes for an immersive experience

votesFunny: if you want to succeed you are going to have to work together with your squad leaders and your commander. It is very important for squad leaders to stay alive as they serve as spawn points for other players within their squad. Squad leaders also have to mark locations for artillery

column16: he or she must give orders to the other squad leaders and fireteams and is also capable of calling in artillery on the locations marked by the squad leaders.  Communication is very important in this game
column17: if you have an important role at least.\n\nThe graphics are also pretty good for a 2011 game

reviewText:
Red Orchestra and Rising Storm are truly amazing WW2 tactical shooters. Very realistic and challenging gameplay with no room for silly mistakes. Player can take a role of one of few different infantry classes (like rifleman, team leader, sniper, tank hunter etc. ) and also can be a part of a tank crew. German Panzer IV and soviet T-34 are very good addition in the game and both are very well modelled and detailed. Weapons behaviour is very realistic and weapon ballistics/accurace is also well executed.
Rising Storm will take the player to the Pacific Ocean theatre of WW2.
US Army and Imperial Army are extremely well done. Using US superior firepower to take stategic locations in places like Iwo Jima or Saipan is a great experience.
In my opinion the thing that makes this game so great is definitely the Japanesse Imperial Army. They do not posses such good equipment as US forces, but they rely on their unmatched feriocity and fanatical determination to fight to the last man. Booby traps, ambushes and other treacherous tactics are in common use. Watching an entire squad rushing into enemy position with swords/bayonets/grenades and fanatical screams is something that could not be forgot - Banzai Charge is an unique gameplay mechanic of the Imperial Army.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Truly an immersive, horrifying, amazing, and realistic portrayal of WWII. Everything from the bullet physics to the inside of the tanks are realistic in their behavior and modeling, the graphics are pretty good and the action is intense. Even the voice acting deserves a mention, from hearing a soldier gurgle and cough after being shot in the neck to hearing a dying Wehrmacht soldier  screaming in German for his mother. This game captures the feeling of the era. The game does, however, have a steep learning curve, and is very unforgiving to new players. It has also personally ruined me, as I am unable to enjoy traditional twitch fps games such as COD since playing this.

reviewText:
After investing a decent amount of time into this game, i finally decided to write this review.
Let's start with the most important thing: Do I recommend this game? Yes.
Now let's see why.

Community: Mature  - you won't see any twelve year olds running about depicting their sexual fantasies with either of your parents.
Helpful - i really can't remember a single game related question they refused to answer
Active - EU servers are usually full
I'll give the community a strong 10/10.

Gameplay: Now this one is more tricky.
The mechanics are not always at their brightest, especially when vaulting over obstacles, but there are a lot of good stuff to make up for that. My favourite is the scare-o-meter suppression, which pretty much forces you to stay in cover, when you would order your soldier from your comfy seat to stand up and take a chance at killing your shooter. Also, folks tend to criticise the hitbox system in the game, but don't buy that. The hitboxes are fine.
Talking about hitting targets, it must be said that tank combat is quite engaging, as it requires at gunners and tank gunners to aim for weakspots (engine, crew member, etc), and not just any random part of the hulking metal deathmachines.
Also, your soldier does his best to put his weapon against anything to improve accuracy, which is pretty cool (e.g. against trees, if you can lean in close enough).

Gameplay-mechanics: 8/10

Now a bit more about the player" part of the gameplay. The game has a few game modes

reviewText:
Renember when games used to be hard? When a few shots was all it took for you to have to start all over again, unlike games like CoD, where you can take three times as many bullets as you would in real life? Tripwire Interactive renembers, and as such, made a brutal but fair shooter. Red Orchestra 2.

If you can get over the steep learning curve and how brutal this game is, you'll enjoy it. I recommend you read a guide on Steam and start playing on Action mode with a few people; going through the tutorial will also help.

Simply put, this game is set in WW2 and it is an FPS (Duh). You are pitched in battles with Axis Germans against Allied Russians (Or Americans against Japanese, if your playing Rising Storm). It's a team based shooter with different classes and highly realistic weapons. (Tired of high powered rifles to not kill with one hit, meaning automatic rifles always come out on top? Well, not in this game!)

The great thing is, Tripwire Interactive constantly pumps out free DLC with maps, weapons etc. And, they also listen to the community! (The main reason why I love TI) The game is constantly being improved, so if you do find a bug, simply report it to TI and it should be fixed pretty soon. If you enjoy shooters or World War 2 games, this is for you.

Good points:
-Great Gameplay
-Realistic Functions+Gameplay
-Pretty good graphics+Textures
-Great Community
-Responsive developers

Bad Points:
-Steepe learning curve
-It's difficult (Which is good for some, like me)

Final Verdict:
9/10

Gameplay is great and realistic, graphics pretty good. Overall, great game. Highly recommended for fans of shooters and for ones who want to re-live the horror and brutality of World War Two.

reviewText: If you download it before 6pm tomorrow (24/04/14) then this game is free to keep forever! So why are you wasting my time reading my review, and not downloading it! On a more serious note the game is a WW2 simulator utilising the Unreal Engine for brilliant graphics and decent FPS. There is a role in the game for everyone eg. Machine Gunner, Assault, Marksman and even Tanks for you to use (and abuse... perhaps... not really recommended). It is team based and action packed, in no other game can you experience something so close to the reality of the brutal house to house room to room fighting in 1942 Stalingrad (with funny German accents as a bonus). As it is free, there is really no reason for you not to give it a go and install it! (Ignore the singleplayer btw its pretty laggy (unless of course it is your duty to unlock every single achievement, in which case go for it!)) In conclusion this is a hardcore WW2 sim with realistic environments and brilliant teamwork! So, download it now!

reviewText:
Great game, I love how Tripwire have kept a realistic feel without comprimising on fun, hectic largescale battles.

MULTIPLAYER:

At first the game can seem quite overwhelming and the ranking system is hard to grasp.
There are three types of ranking in the game: honour, class and weapon.
Just by playing the game you will recieve XP and you will rank up in the traditional way of gaining enough XP, then increasing in level. Then there is class ranking; the more you play a particular class, the class will gain ranks (there are three class ranks). Each rank in a particular class may give you a new weapon, but will make the character look more 'battle hardened'. Then there is weapon ranking, at level 0 your weapon will have no attachments, no perks and will be completely stock in terms of upgrades. When you reach level 25 just by playing with it, you may(or may not) gain an attachement for your weapon e.g. a bayonet. Also your weapon handling will increase, which means your reload, bolting action and ADS will be faster. Your weapon will also get a more 'looked after finish ' to it. Upon reaching level 50 you may get an attachement, you handling will increase again and you weapon will  have a shiny polished finish.

I have taken my time to explain the ranking system as many people have asked me about it ingame.

Realism mode for multiplayer seems to be very popular, unlike the classic mode. Realism is the 'hardcore' mode of the game. It is by far the best mode and obviously the more realistic. Bullet damage is increased and there is no aiming dead-zone (as you pivot the direction the bullet will go isn't locked to the center of the screen, if you don't understand you will when you play it). As for servers go they are all very stable, with barely any dedicated Tripwire servers there will always be a server for you. There are usually about 5 or six servers up at any one moment.

CAMPAIGN:

It has a good campaign which is a good length, split into two parts, the Russian campaign and the German Campaign.
I have one problem though; the campaign missions are styled like the multiplayer missions, you will need to capture areas just like you do in the multiplayer and you will play on exactly the same maps and instead of live players you play with AI.
I must commend Tripwire for including this as not many modern games are styled in this way, but it just fails to keep you playing, with no interesting plot I feel the game is weakened by the campaign.


RISING STORM:

The Rising Storm standalone game/DLC features the RO2 multiplayer but set in the pacific with the Japanese and the Americans. I feel that Rising Storm is a much more refined game and stamps out most of the bugs seen in RO2 multiplayer. RS does not have a campaign.

Campaign = 6/10
RO2 Multiplayer = 8.5/10
Rising Storm = 9.5/10

NOTE!::: IF YOU WANT THE RED ORCHESTRA 2 MULTIPLAYER, BUY RISING STORM, BOTH MULTIPLAYERS ARE PART OF THE RISING STORM DLC. IF YOU WANT THE RO2 CAMPAIGN JUST BUY THE BASE GAME. I DON'T THINK YOU GET RO2 MULTIPLAYER WITH RO2 ANYMORE.

reviewText: This game is the most immersive, engaging, atmospheric, and brutal WW2 shooter on the market. It's like every life you are the director of your own war movie but without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ romance subplots. The pacing is brilliant, sometimes you will slowly moving up on the flank hearing a couple shots once in a while and a stray bullet might go over your head. Another time you will be pinned down by heavy fire in a foxhole with your friends just trying to desperately return fire. The sound design in this game is phenomenal, every bullet and gun has a brutal impact. The recoil is hefty and honest. The ragdolls are immersive especially the death screams and the way the bodies just lean against things just adds to the complete WW2 experience. Seriously addicting game. If you are a WW2 multiplayer fanatic and you haven't played this game, you are doing yourself a great dishonor.

reviewText: A hardcore shooter to separate the men from the console ♥♥♥♥♥. A different, more cereberal style than CoD's mindless run-and-gun.  Teamwork matters. Classes are limited and serve distinct roles; vanilla riflemen are equally valued to LMGers and SMG assault troops.  I've never seen a game where players mimic real-world tactics - i.e. even on pub servers cover each other and 'leapfrog' towards the objectives; player pause to allow allies to toss a grenade in the window (instead of leaping in after it, getting tked, and punishing). Even the damage system makes sense - instead of a magically refilling 'health bar'; if hit in a non-vital area, you have a few seconds to take cover and bandage yourself, or you die. A torso or headshot is 1-shot death from any rifle-calibre weapon. Put CoD aside and give this a try.

reviewText: I was charging a state-house with ten of my comrades when fascist artillery whistled down. A big red ball of fire and shards of metal formed thirty feet in front of me. Body parts went terminal velocity and connected with other comrades, killing them. I was blown back with injured legs, bleeding gallons per minute. I was able to bandage myself up and find cover. I took note of the blast area. Five unrecognizable bodies were in a pile, four other bodies were strewn about. One of the limbless husks were still screaming in pain, only to be drown out by incoming machinegun fire. Out of ten chargers, I was the sole survivor. The images still haunt me when I take my annual sail from Murmansk...\n\nPPsH 41/10, would break legs and watch men with organs tossed about die again...

reviewText:
8/10
Let me be honest, I do love this game and I enjoy playing it. But it has some rather annoying quirks about it. ( like all games)

Quirks

-Not many people play RO2 so there is limited servers and even more limited that play custom maps with players. ( the game is not dead!)
-Almost always it seems the Germans win because most vet players pick Axis every time stacking teams.
-The suppression effect is a little exagerated in the game. IE; Aiming down sights and incoming enemy fire will cause the    rifle to jerk around uncontrollably.
- The russians all have brand new very BRIGHT uniforms which the Germans can easily target at range, and even in dark windows.
- unlike the Original RO, RO2 has very limited tank combat. Only a hand full of combined arms maps and one main tank orientated map.
- Most popular servers will most certainly pick the following maps. Bridges, Grain elevator, Appartments, ect Over and over again.
- Spawning is VERY annoying, usually spawning so far behind from the objective it takes forever to renforce your team. and usually a 24 second respawn wave.


The good stuff.

- Excellent detail, weapons loading fireing and tank detail is outstanding.
- Combat is very fun and as challenging as you want it to be.
- Ballistics are pretty accurate although I find 200m sight adjustments works best at 100m.
- Losts to level up on and it doesn't level up too quickly.
- The maps are very well done and have a great atmosphere. ( dark, cold full of death)
- sounds are also pretty good however the recently added MG42 could have had a bit more time spent on the sound.
- the controls are not overwhelming like some simulation games and RO2 is not overly difficult to play. also has a training mode and single player level mode.
- Graphics are excellent usuing the Unreal engine.


I would reccomend RO2, it is very fun and addicitng. The quicks mentioned are not ment to discourage and you will easily forget about them once you try the game. A lot of them have to do with servers.

reviewText:
My review and how the game honestly is.

Part 1:

A game that takes it's time, or at least tries to, make the game have atmosphere to it. That being under fire from a barrage of enemy guns or machine guns, you can feel sucked into the moment. Especially when you have teamwork. It can also get exciting when that happens as well.

Action, is ok if you are starting out, BUT do not keep playing action. Guns do damage like you are shooting people with body armor, like the game wanted to be COD

Realism, where the game is at for sure. It's so satisfying to kill someone in this game. To cut them down with a machine gun is just... mmmmmm. Realism gives the guns power to them, making them feel like an actual gun. I've played COD, and well I still don't feel sucked in to it. Unlike RO2.
